<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-604] combining properties which use 3+ part names discards entries as of Commons 1.6+</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-604</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When two property files are combined using commons config 1.5, the aggregate configuration returns an expected result of 6 entries. If Commons configuration 1.6 or higher is used, the resulting set drops to  which is not expected. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The property names include 2, 3 or 4 part names X.Y, X.Y.Z etc and it appears that as of 1.6 if the names are arranged in 2 part, then 3 part etc that the combiner returns the expected result.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There does not appear to be any release notes etc that would suggest  that this isn&apos;t a defect versus an intended implementation change.&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12842615">CONFIGURATION-604</key>
            <summary>combining properties which use 3+ part names discards entries as of Commons 1.6+</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="the6campbells">N Campbell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 3 Jul 2015 18:47:00 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:20:55 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 13 Jul 2015 20:22:59 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.6</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14613397" author="the6campbells" created="Fri, 3 Jul 2015 18:48:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Simple source&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;import java.util.Iterator;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.configuration.CombinedConfiguration;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.configuration.ConfigurationException;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.configuration.PropertiesConfiguration;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.configuration.tree.NodeCombiner;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.configuration.tree.OverrideCombiner;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class CommonsIssue {	&lt;br/&gt;
	public static String propFile1 = &quot;c:\\temp&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;A.properties&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
	public static String propFile2 = &quot;c:\\temp&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;B.properties&quot;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	public static void main( String[] args ) throws ConfigurationException &lt;/p&gt;
{
		testCombindedConfig();	 		
	}

&lt;p&gt;	public static void testCombindedConfig() throws ConfigurationException {&lt;br/&gt;
		NodeCombiner combiner = new OverrideCombiner();&lt;br/&gt;
		CombinedConfiguration combinedConfig = new CombinedConfiguration(combiner);		&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		PropertiesConfiguration conf1 = new PropertiesConfiguration();&lt;br/&gt;
		conf1.setDelimiterParsingDisabled(true);&lt;br/&gt;
		conf1.setThrowExceptionOnMissing(true);			&lt;br/&gt;
		conf1.load(propFile1);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		combinedConfig.addConfiguration(conf1);		&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		PropertiesConfiguration conf2 = new PropertiesConfiguration();&lt;br/&gt;
		conf2.setDelimiterParsingDisabled(true);&lt;br/&gt;
		conf2.setThrowExceptionOnMissing(true);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		conf2.load(propFile2);&lt;br/&gt;
		combinedConfig.addConfiguration(conf2);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		@SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
		Iterator&amp;lt;String&amp;gt; keys = combinedConfig.getKeys();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		while (keys.hasNext()) &lt;/p&gt;
{
			String key = keys.next();
			System.out.println(key + &quot;=&quot; + combinedConfig.getString(key));

		}
&lt;p&gt;		&lt;br/&gt;
	}&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A.properties&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.simpleCase=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.between=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.isDistinctFrom=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y=true&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;B.properties&lt;br/&gt;
x.y=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.between=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.comparison=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.in=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.isDistinctFrom=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.simpleCase=true&lt;/p&gt;


</comment>
                            <comment id="14614033" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 4 Jul 2015 20:03:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This seems to be a pretty old change since version 1.6 was released years ago.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To make sure I fully understand the problem, could you please specify exactly the expected result and the actual result? (Or even better: could you transform your demo code fragment to a unit test?)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14614045" author="the6campbells" created="Sat, 4 Jul 2015 20:25:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Expected answer is 6 as returned when using 1.5&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;x.y=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.simpleCase=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.between=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.isDistinctFrom=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.comparison=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.in=true&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Switch to 1.6+ and you get 4&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;x.y.simpleCase=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.between=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.isDistinctFrom=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y=true&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Stay with 1.6 and re-order the 2-part entry in A.properties so it appears before 3 part names (x.y=true) and you get 6 again&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;x.y=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.simpleCase=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.between=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.isDistinctFrom=false&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.comparison=true&lt;br/&gt;
x.y.in=true&lt;/p&gt;



</comment>
                            <comment id="14625273" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 13 Jul 2015 20:22:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A fix was committed in revision 1690812. The problem was in the construction of a hierarical configuration from a flat one; the algorithm could indeed produce different results based on the order of the keys in the source configuration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I did not look into the old sources for Configuration 1.5 to find out by which change the problem was introduced. The fix should make the resulting hierarchical configuration more independent on the order of property keys.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Many thanks for spotting this!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-602] DatabaseConfiguration doesn&apos;t reload from database.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-602</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have successfully setup Apache configuration to read from a database table by using DatabaseConfigurationProvider. However when I change the database property in the DB table and read the property again, it always has the previous value and not the updated value from Table.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;My code is:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;b&gt;Setup:&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
			DefaultConfigurationBuilder builder = new DefaultConfigurationBuilder(propFileUrl);&lt;br/&gt;
			DefaultConfigurationBuilder.ConfigurationProvider provider = new DatabaseConfigurationProvider();&lt;br/&gt;
			builder.addConfigurationProvider(&quot;database&quot;, provider);&lt;br/&gt;
			ReloadingStrategy strategy = new FileChangedReloadingStrategy(); &lt;br/&gt;
			((FileChangedReloadingStrategy) strategy).setRefreshDelay(5000);&lt;br/&gt;
			builder.setReloadingStrategy(strategy);			&lt;br/&gt;
                        combinedConfig = builder.getConfiguration(true);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;b&gt;Config.xml:&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                         &amp;lt;configuration&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
                         &amp;lt;database jndi=&quot;jdbc/semsDs&quot; table=&quot;CSW_APPL_PROPERTIES&quot; keyColumn=&quot;PROP_NAME&quot; valueColumn=&quot;PROP_VALUE&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
                         &amp;lt;/configuration&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;b&gt;To access table property:&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
String dbProp = combinedConfig.getString(&quot;TEST_PROP&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;b&gt;Steps to recreate:&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Setup Apache database configuration as above.&lt;br/&gt;
2) Access the property from DB table TEST_PROP=TEMP_1&lt;br/&gt;
3) Now change the TEST_PROP value to TEMP_2 in the DB table.&lt;br/&gt;
4) Access the property from  the same DB Table.&lt;br/&gt;
5) Property Value still says TEMP_1.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows, Eclipse, apache commons 1.10&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12832752">CONFIGURATION-602</key>
            <summary>DatabaseConfiguration doesn&apos;t reload from database.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="chethanjs">Chethan Shankar_apache</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>DatabaseConfigurationProvider</label>
                            <label>commons-configuration</label>
                            <label>configuration</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 26 May 2015 15:41:35 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 28 May 2015 19:33:28 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 28 May 2015 19:32:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.10</version>
                                                    <component>Build</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                    <timeoriginalestimate seconds="86400">24h</timeoriginalestimate>
                            <timeestimate seconds="86400">24h</timeestimate>
                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="14561581" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 27 May 2015 19:41:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The reloading functionality as implemented in the 1.x series is limited to file-based configurations; there is simply no reloading support for DatabaseConfiguration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In version 2.0 (currently available as alpha release), situation has improved. The reloading mechanism is now more generic and can be customized. You can find a description of the new features in the updated user&apos;s guide:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/howto_reloading.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/howto_reloading.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, the new reloading mechanism will not work out of the box with DatabaseConfiguration either. The reason is that it is very much application-specific when checks for a reload are to be executed and which triggers are to be used - you probably do not want that each access to a combined configuration causes a full scan of the configuration database table. So, Commons Configuration 2.0 gives you enhanced flexibility in this area, but you still have to write some code on your own to implement your specific use case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you agree, I will close this ticket as &quot;Won&apos;t fix&quot; for the reasons outlined above.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14561626" author="chethanjs" created="Wed, 27 May 2015 20:10:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree. Thanks for your reply.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14563547" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 28 May 2015 19:32:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing as &quot;Won&apos;t Fix&quot; as was the outcome of discussion.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-601] honor values that are string literals</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-601</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Parsing the following file, does not honor keys that are string literals such as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;some_key = &quot;hi there, would you like to (play with me)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;yields:&lt;br/&gt;
key: some_key&lt;br/&gt;
val: &quot;hi there&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;rather than the expected result of:&lt;br/&gt;
key: some_key&lt;br/&gt;
val: &quot;hi there, would you like to (play with me)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12829369">CONFIGURATION-601</key>
            <summary>honor values that are string literals</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kalensk">Kalen Krempely</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 12 May 2015 22:22:27 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 13 May 2015 19:35:55 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>1.9</version>
                                                    <component>Interpolation</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14542531" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 13 May 2015 19:35:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Indeed, we do not honer string literals. I fear this will not be easy to support, it comes with a whole bunch of follow-up issues, e.g. support for different quote character, escaping, line continuation, etc.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In your specific case, you are hit by the comma character being interpreted as list delimiter. The user guide describes multiple approaches to work around this problem:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide_v1.10/howto_basicfeatures.html#List_handling&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide_v1.10/howto_basicfeatures.html#List_handling&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide_v1.10/howto_properties.html#Lists_and_arrays&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide_v1.10/howto_properties.html#Lists_and_arrays&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide_v1.10/howto_properties.html#Special_Characters_and_Escaping&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide_v1.10/howto_properties.html#Special_Characters_and_Escaping&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Note that in the upcoming version 2.0 the behavior of list delimiter parsing has changed. It is then disabled by default (due to the many problems it has created) and has to be explicitly enabled if desired.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-600] Loading xml configuration file as a stream does not work with multi configurations</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-600</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When using the commons configuration inside a WAR loading a XML file works fine when done like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;InputStream is = this.getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(&quot;/conf/main.xml&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
builder.load(is);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem is when the main.xml reference other xml files:&lt;br/&gt;
configuration&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;xml fileName=&quot;child1.xml&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/configuration&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the structure of the war is:&lt;br/&gt;
/&lt;br/&gt;
/classes&lt;br/&gt;
/conf/child1.xml&lt;br/&gt;
/conf/main.xml&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There seems to be no way to pick up child1.xml from main.xml when loading main.xml as a stream.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12827663">CONFIGURATION-600</key>
            <summary>Loading xml configuration file as a stream does not work with multi configurations</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="johhen">John Henriksson</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 6 May 2015 13:49:05 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:20:45 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 25 May 2015 18:05:16 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.8</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14531228" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 6 May 2015 19:18:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I assume you are using &lt;tt&gt;DefaultConfigurationBuilder&lt;/tt&gt; for loading the file, do you? This class has a method for setting a base path. The base path is taken into account when resolving child configuration files.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can set the base path to a URL (in string form) obtained via this.getClass().getClassLoader().getResource(). I am not sure whether this works with URLs pointing to elements in a jar file though, but you should give it a try.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14542535" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 13 May 2015 19:37:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Any updates here? Were you able to solve the problem?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14543371" author="johhen" created="Thu, 14 May 2015 08:20:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, I am using the DefaultConfigurationBuilder but I could not get it to work even with setting the base path. In the end I externalised the configuration files (outside the war) and loaded the location of the configuration files from a java system property that I set starting up the application.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14546888" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 16 May 2015 18:40:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for your feedback.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think your use case is valid and should be supported. I will have a look, but may need some time. I will add my findings to this ticket.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14557837" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 24 May 2015 20:31:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Finally I managed to look into this. I tried to simulate your use case and created a jar with a structure similar to the one you described:&lt;br/&gt;
/conf/jar-main.xml&lt;br/&gt;
/conf/jar-test.properties&lt;br/&gt;
/conf/jar-test.properties.xml&lt;br/&gt;
/conf/jar-test.xml&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The first file is the combined configuration definition file with the following content:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-xml&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;configuration&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;properties fileName=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;jar-test.properties&quot;&lt;/span&gt; config-name=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;props&quot;&lt;/span&gt;/&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;properties fileName=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;jar-test.properties.xml&quot;&lt;/span&gt;/&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;xml fileName=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;jar-test.xml&quot;&lt;/span&gt; config-name=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;xml&quot;&lt;/span&gt;/&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/configuration&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This file - and all the referenced configuration sources - could be loaded successfully with the following code fragement (this uses Commons Configuration 2.0alpha; &lt;tt&gt;CombinedConfigurationBuilder&lt;/tt&gt; corresponds to &lt;tt&gt;DefaultConfigurationBuilder&lt;/tt&gt; in 1.x):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testReadFromJar() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; MalformedURLException, ConfigurationException {
    URL url = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; URL(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;jar:file:src/test/resources/config.jar!/conf/jar-main.xml&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
    builder.configure(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Parameters().fileBased().setURL(url));
    CombinedConfiguration configuration = builder.getConfiguration();
    assertTrue(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Not loaded&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, configuration.getBoolean(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;configuration.loaded&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So rather than loading the file from a stream, I used the URL directly. (Here it is hard-coded, but of course, it can be obtained via getClassLoader().getResource().) Then relative paths referenced from the main configuration file are automatically resolved; there is no need to set a base path. When reading the file from a stream, however, there is no absolute path which could be used for resolving files.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maybe this use case can be explicitly mentioned in the documentation. But otherwise, I do not think that this is a bug or requires a fix in the code base.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14558422" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 25 May 2015 18:05:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;An example of loading a combined configuration from a jar has been added to the user&apos;s guide.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-599] CombinedConfiguration fails to merge correctly when one configuration only contains one property</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-599</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When using a CombinedConfiguration it fails to merge properties located in both of the configurations if one of the configuration only contains 1 property.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;CombinedConfiguration.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;	&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; void main(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] args)
	{
		NodeCombiner combiner = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; MergeCombiner();
		combiner.addListNode(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;module&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
		CombinedConfiguration configuration = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; CombinedConfiguration(combiner);
		
		XMLConfiguration xmlConf = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; XMLConfiguration();
		xmlConf.addProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;modules.module&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;1&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
		xmlConf.addProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;modules.module&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;2&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
		xmlConf.addProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;modules.module&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;3&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
		
		XMLConfiguration xmlConf2 = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; XMLConfiguration();
		xmlConf2.addProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;modules.module&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;4&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);

		configuration.addConfiguration(xmlConf);
		configuration.addConfiguration(xmlConf2);
		
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//THIS WILL NOT PRINT THE VALUE 4 FROM XMLCONF2
&lt;/span&gt;		&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt;(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; s : configuration.getStringArray(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;modules.module&quot;&lt;/span&gt;))
		{
			&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(s);
		}
		
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println();
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//Now add one more additional property
&lt;/span&gt;		xmlConf2.addProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;modules.module&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;5&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
		
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//NOW IT WILL PRINT BOTH VALUE 4 AND 5 FROM XMLCONF2
&lt;/span&gt;		&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt;(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; s : configuration.getStringArray(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;modules.module&quot;&lt;/span&gt;))
		{
			&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(s);
		}
	}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12825925">CONFIGURATION-599</key>
            <summary>CombinedConfiguration fails to merge correctly when one configuration only contains one property</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="langen">Martin Lindgren</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 29 Apr 2015 12:21:48 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 4 May 2015 19:34:01 +0000</updated>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14520101" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 29 Apr 2015 20:02:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Are you sure you are using the correct node combiner for your use case? &lt;tt&gt;MergeCombiner&lt;/tt&gt; implements some pretty special merging rules; have a look at the Javadocs at &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/apidocs/org/apache/commons/configuration2/tree/MergeCombiner.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/apidocs/org/apache/commons/configuration2/tree/MergeCombiner.html&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Try UnionCombiner; this class always generates a union of the configurations involved. Examples for the different combiners can be found in the user&apos;s guide: &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/howto_combinedconfiguration.html#Node_combiners&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/howto_combinedconfiguration.html#Node_combiners&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14520923" author="langen" created="Thu, 30 Apr 2015 06:06:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thank you for your answer.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;UnionCombiner&lt;/tt&gt; gives me the expected result for the given example, but I am not sure yet if I can change to that because many of our projects are currently using the &lt;tt&gt;MergeCombiner&lt;/tt&gt; and changing may have unexpected results on other projects.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am not sure that I am using the correct node combiner, but it seems strange to me that my provided example wouldn&apos;t work with a &lt;tt&gt;MergeCombiner&lt;/tt&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would like to know if the &lt;tt&gt;MergeCombiner&lt;/tt&gt; works as intended with the provided example. If so,  I will have to investigate if I can change to the &lt;tt&gt;UnionCombiner&lt;/tt&gt; without breaking any functionality. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14522124" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 30 Apr 2015 19:49:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have never used &lt;tt&gt;MergeCombiner&lt;/tt&gt; myself. So the only reference is the API documentation of this class. There is the point&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Only a single node in the second file is considered a match to the node in the first file.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Can this be related to your problem?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You said that you use {MergeCombiner}} because it is used elsewhere in the project. This seems a bit strange to me. I would expect that you have some concrete requirements and based on these choose the appropriate combiner.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14526330" author="langen" created="Mon, 4 May 2015 07:01:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes it could be related to my problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We have multiple projects which depends on an internal framework which sets up common parts of project settings such as the configurations. This internal framework use the &lt;tt&gt;MergeCombiner&lt;/tt&gt;. I have solved the problem by adding functionality to the framework to specify which combiner a specific project should have.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So if the &lt;tt&gt;MergeCombiner&lt;/tt&gt; works as expected with the provided example this issue can be rejected. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-598] There are 2 different ConfigurationBuilder interfaces</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-598</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;(This is my first time entering a bug here; at least searching with ConfigurationBuilder here did not bring any relevant issues so I wanted to post this)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are 2 different ConfigurationBuilder interfaces: &lt;br/&gt;
one is &lt;tt&gt;org.apache.commons.configuration2.ConfigurationBuilder&lt;/tt&gt; and other is&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;tt&gt;org.apache.commons.configuration2.builder.ConfigurationBuilder&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The base package has &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Configuration 	getConfiguration()
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;while the builder package has &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;T 	getConfiguration()
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;and the (&amp;lt;T extends Configuration&amp;gt; as generic parameter in the interface)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I assume this is a bug, since nothing implements the base package one and all ConfigurationBuilder implementations implement the one in the builder subpackage. It is at least confusing in case the base package one is intended just for clients to implement. Also documentation points to the builder package one.&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12820052">CONFIGURATION-598</key>
            <summary>There are 2 different ConfigurationBuilder interfaces</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bjakke">Bjarne Bostr&#246;m</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 10 Apr 2015 12:38:48 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:20:52 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 10 Apr 2015 20:13:09 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0-alpha1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14490291" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 10 Apr 2015 20:13:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;You are completely right, the &lt;tt&gt;ConfigurationBuilder&lt;/tt&gt; interface in the base package is legacy and should have been removed. This is now fixed in SVN in revision 1672747.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Many thanks for spotting this!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_12310220" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:firstresponsedate">
                        <customfieldname>Date of First Response</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>Fri, 10 Apr 2015 20:13:09 +0000</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-597] Periods in INI file keys not parsed correctly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-597</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I am using HierarchicalINIConfiguration.  When I try to parse an INI file with periods in the key definitions, something goes wrong, and the periods are parsed incorrectly.  For example, my INI file looks like&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;foods&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
breakfast.drink=oj&lt;br/&gt;
lunch.drink=milk&lt;br/&gt;
dinner.drink=beer&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;And my java code looks like&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;File configFile = new File(&quot;path/to/the/file.ini&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
HierarchicalINIConfiguration config = new HierarchichalINIConfiguration(configFile);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;config.getSection(&quot;foods&quot;).getString(&quot;breakfast.drink&quot;, null);  // null&lt;br/&gt;
config.getSection(&quot;foods&quot;).getString(&quot;breakfast..drink&quot;, null); // &quot;oj&quot;&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Note the double period in the second one.  Is this something I&apos;m doing wrong, or is there a bug in the parser?  Are periods such as this even allowed in INI files?  I can&apos;t find anything explicitly saying either way.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12779635">CONFIGURATION-597</key>
            <summary>Periods in INI file keys not parsed correctly</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="8">Not A Problem</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="Ryan Fox">Ryan Fox</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 4 Mar 2015 23:44:41 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 20 Mar 2015 18:39:53 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 20 Mar 2015 18:39:53 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.10</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14349458" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 5 Mar 2015 21:07:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is expected behavior. It is documented in the user&apos;s guide:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/howto_hierarchical.html#Escaping_special_characters&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/howto_hierarchical.html#Escaping_special_characters&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem is basically that hierarchical configurations use the dot &quot;.&quot; as delimiter character for property keys. So if a key already contains a dot, it has to be treated in a special way. The link above describes the syntax used for this purpose.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14349466" author="Ryan Fox" created="Thu, 5 Mar 2015 21:10:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks, couldn&apos;t find that one before!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14371828" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 20 Mar 2015 18:39:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Escaping of property keys works as expected.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

            <title>[CONFIGURATION-594] Adding CData to xml property</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-594</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Need to add CDATA into XML Property element, but special character are getting added. Here is my code. Please give your thoughts on the same.&lt;br/&gt;
Here is the code.&lt;br/&gt;
String cDataTagStart=&quot;&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;&amp;lt;![CDATA[&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
String cDataTagEnd=&quot;]]&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;&amp;gt;&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
credentialsURL =cDataTagStart+credentialsURL+cDataTagEnd;&lt;br/&gt;
xmlContentOfMetaData = CredentialProvider.getInstance();&lt;br/&gt;
xmlContentOfMetaData.addProperty(&quot;Resource(-1).ResourceName&quot;, resourceName);&lt;br/&gt;
xmlContentOfMetaData.addProperty(&quot;Resource.ResourceURL&quot;, credentialsURL);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But Special characters are getting added&lt;br/&gt;
ResourceName&amp;gt;TESTRESOURCENAME&amp;lt;/ResourceName&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;ResourceURL&amp;gt;\&amp;lt;![CDATA&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;TESTCredentialsURLS2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;]\&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/ResourceURL&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

&lt;p&gt;&quot;Internal Server Error&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The server encountered an internal error or misconfiguration and was unable to complete your request.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-586] DefaultConfiguration has unspecified dependency on commons collections</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-586</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I was going through the guide &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/howto_configurationbuilder.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/howto_configurationbuilder.html&lt;/a&gt; to parse an xml file and I hit a CNFE on org.apache.commons.collections.CollectionUtils. Maven&apos;s dependency for commons-configuration provides no indication that commons collections is needed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It should either have commons-collections as a dependency or the use of CollectionUtils should be worked around.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12728707">CONFIGURATION-586</key>
            <summary>DefaultConfiguration has unspecified dependency on commons collections</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-585] Hardcoded Parameters prevents correct initialisation of XML DocumentBuilder</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-585</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;XMLConfiguration:&lt;br/&gt;
 protected DocumentBuilder createDocumentBuilder()&lt;br/&gt;
            throws ParserConfigurationException&lt;br/&gt;
    {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (getDocumentBuilder() != null)&lt;/p&gt;
        {
            return getDocumentBuilder();
        }
&lt;p&gt;        else&lt;br/&gt;
        {&lt;br/&gt;
            DocumentBuilderFactory factory = DocumentBuilderFactory&lt;br/&gt;
                    .newInstance();&lt;br/&gt;
            if (isValidating())&lt;br/&gt;
            {&lt;br/&gt;
                factory.setValidating(true);&lt;br/&gt;
                if (isSchemaValidation())&lt;/p&gt;
                {
                    factory.setNamespaceAware(true);
                    factory.setAttribute(JAXP_SCHEMA_LANGUAGE, W3C_XML_SCHEMA);
                }
&lt;p&gt;            }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            DocumentBuilder result = factory.newDocumentBuilder();&lt;br/&gt;
            result.setEntityResolver(this.entityResolver);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            if (isValidating())&lt;br/&gt;
            {&lt;br/&gt;
                // register an error handler which detects validation errors&lt;br/&gt;
                result.setErrorHandler(new DefaultHandler()&lt;br/&gt;
                {&lt;br/&gt;
                    @Override&lt;br/&gt;
                    public void error(SAXParseException ex) throws SAXException&lt;/p&gt;
                    {
                        throw ex;
                    }
&lt;p&gt;                });&lt;br/&gt;
            }&lt;br/&gt;
            return result;&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
There is no way to externally set any of these parameters&lt;br/&gt;
I propose 2 changes&lt;br/&gt;
1)read properties from pom.xml&lt;br/&gt;
2)morph this into a XMLConfigurationPlugin which will run goal to set the params from configuration for new commons-configuration-plugin&lt;br/&gt;
(Bug originally reported by Ron DiFrango from CapitalOne)&lt;br/&gt;
Martin Gainty&lt;br/&gt;
11 July 2014&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;JDK 1.7.0.45&lt;br/&gt;
MvN 3.0.5&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12726918">CONFIGURATION-585</key>
            <summary>Hardcoded Parameters prevents correct initialisation of XML DocumentBuilder</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/blocker.svg">Blocker</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mgainty@hotmail.com">Martin Gainty</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>XMLConfiguration</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 12 Jul 2014 01:34:06 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 9 Sep 2014 18:02:28 +0000</updated>

                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="14059837" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 12 Jul 2014 16:20:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I am sorry, but I do not understand this ticket. What exactly do you mean by hard-coded parameters and what should be read from a pom or should be made available from a Maven plug-in?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When reading an XML configuration file you can of course set parameters like the validation mode on the &lt;tt&gt;XMLConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; instance. You can even set a custom &lt;tt&gt;DocumentBuilder&lt;/tt&gt; object which is configured according to your needs.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14063992" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 16 Jul 2014 19:49:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Any feedback on this one? I tend to close this ticket as invalid because I have no clue what you are after.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14067924" author="mgainty@hotmail.com" created="Sun, 20 Jul 2014 13:07:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;the dev is relying on Hardcoded Parameters here:&lt;br/&gt;
if factory.setValidating(true); //why is this hardcoded?&lt;/p&gt;
{
   if (isSchemaValidation()) //another hardcoded parameter?
    else BLOW UP 
   }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;br/&gt;
when I ran the library locally all of the testcases failed or produced errors..I found this&lt;br/&gt;
    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Returns the root node of this hierarchical configuration. This method&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;exists for backwards compatibility only. New code should use the&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;{@link #getRootNode()}
&lt;p&gt; method instead, which operates on&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the preferred data type 
{@code ConfigurationNode}
&lt;p&gt;.&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@return the root node&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    public org.w3c.dom.Node getRoot()
    { .... }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;br/&gt;
in other words you are relying on every entity read in to be a XML dom document which of course&lt;br/&gt;
most of them are not ..which testcases produce the most errors?&lt;br/&gt;
1)any testcase reading and parsing properties&lt;br/&gt;
2)any testcase reading and parsing Database reads&lt;br/&gt;
3)any testcase reading and parsing non DOM xml Docs (e.g. Sax OR stax)&lt;br/&gt;
I was an enthusistic supporter of (throw anything at your project and we can read it)&lt;br/&gt;
BUT you have one parse which is for DOM..anything else fails&lt;br/&gt;
to get a better understanding read the AXIOM code to see how they handle XML documents &lt;br/&gt;
DOM, SAX and STAX (they dont touch properties or database reads)&lt;br/&gt;
for now I think a re-architecture is the only solution which will accomodate&lt;br/&gt;
1)SomeKindOfPropertyNode which will read and properly parse properties files and maintain hierarchy&lt;br/&gt;
2)SomeKindOfDBNode which will read and properly parse DB reads and organise into a hierarchy&lt;br/&gt;
3)SomeKindOfXMLSaxNode which will read and properly parse SAX docs and maintain hierarchy&lt;br/&gt;
4)SomeKindOfXMLStaxNode Which will read and properly parse STAX docs and maintain hierarchy&lt;br/&gt;
Martin&lt;br/&gt;
20 July 2014&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="14067982" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 20 Jul 2014 17:04:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Still not sure if I understand what you mean by &apos;hard-coded&apos;. Do you mean it is hard-coded into &lt;tt&gt;XMLConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; that it reads XML documents? Well, this is true, and this is indeed the sole purpose of this class. If you want to read other configuration sources, you can use other specialized classes like &lt;tt&gt;PropertiesConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;DatabaseConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;. This is explained in the user&apos;s guide: &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/overview.html#Using_Configuration&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/userguide/overview.html#Using_Configuration&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So is this actually a request for a kind of auto-detection of the configuration format?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What failing tests are you referring to? Trunk has about ~2500 unit tests, and they all run successfully.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14081366" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 31 Jul 2014 20:05:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;b&gt;ping&lt;/b&gt; Any updates on this one?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-582] PropertiesConfigurationLayout.getCanonicalComment throws StringIndexOutOfBoundsException when line before property has a single space</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-582</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When a properties file has a line with a single space in it, calling getCanonicalComment(&amp;lt;propertyKey&amp;gt;, false) on the PropertiesConfigurationLayout will throw a StringIndexOutOfBoundsException. Below is the stack trace:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; index out of range: 1
	at java.lang.&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;.charAt(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;.java:686)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.PropertiesConfigurationLayout.stripCommentChar(PropertiesConfigurationLayout.java:768)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.PropertiesConfigurationLayout.trimComment(PropertiesConfigurationLayout.java:741)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.PropertiesConfigurationLayout.constructCanonicalComment(PropertiesConfigurationLayout.java:900)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.PropertiesConfigurationLayout.getCanonicalComment(PropertiesConfigurationLayout.java:212)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12721836">CONFIGURATION-582</key>
            <summary>PropertiesConfigurationLayout.getCanonicalComment throws StringIndexOutOfBoundsException when line before property has a single space</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jonus511">Jonathan wu</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 18 Jun 2014 04:51:18 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:20:55 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 10 Sep 2014 14:17:51 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.10</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14034828" author="jonus511" created="Wed, 18 Jun 2014 05:09:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think this is rooted in the fact that PropertiesConfiguration.isCommentLine(line) returns true if the line is blank, but PropertiesConfigurationLayout.stripCommentChar() assumes comment lines always contain comment chars. There&apos;s no length check while trying to match a comment char so you get the error. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14037689" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 19 Jun 2014 19:04:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the report. I will look into it. It should be possible to solve this before the upcoming 2.0 release.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14128516" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 10 Sep 2014 14:17:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in SVN in revision 1623874.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-581] SystemConfiguration can not get the correct system property</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-581</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Currently the SystemConfiguration does not handle the scenario like below&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  System.setProperty(&quot;demoId&quot;, &quot;demoValue&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
  SystemConfiguration sysConf = new SystemConfiguration ();&lt;br/&gt;
  System.setProperties(new Properties(System.getProperties())));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; System.setProperty(&quot;demoId&quot;, &quot;newDemoValue&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
 String propertyFromSysConf = sysConf.getProperty(&quot;demoId&quot;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In the above code the value of propertyFromSysConf is demoValue but not newDemoValue, and I think the correct value should be newDemoValue&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12718549">CONFIGURATION-581</key>
            <summary>SystemConfiguration can not get the correct system property</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-580] Unexpected trimming when value contains escaped delimiter</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-580</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When parsing a property string value containing a delimiter character,&lt;br/&gt;
the resulting String is trimmed.&lt;br/&gt;
See the following example :&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;BaseConfiguration conf = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; BaseConfiguration();
conf.setProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test1&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test\r\n&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
conf.setProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test2&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test\\,test&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
conf.setProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test3&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test\\,test\r\n&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;*&quot;&lt;/span&gt; + conf.getString(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test1&quot;&lt;/span&gt;) + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;*&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;*&quot;&lt;/span&gt; + conf.getString(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test2&quot;&lt;/span&gt;) + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;*&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;*&quot;&lt;/span&gt; + conf.getString(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test3&quot;&lt;/span&gt;) + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;*&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Expected :&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;*test
*
*test,test*
*test,test
*
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Actual:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;*test
*
*test,test*
*test,test*
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This is caused by the &lt;tt&gt;flatten&lt;/tt&gt; method in &lt;tt&gt;PropertyConverter&lt;/tt&gt; which calls &lt;tt&gt;split(value,delimiter)&lt;/tt&gt; which results in&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;tt&gt;split(value,delimiter,true)&lt;/tt&gt; causing the trimming.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There is a workaround by using the value from another property :&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;test1=test\,test
test2=${test1}\r\n
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12716740">CONFIGURATION-580</key>
            <summary>Unexpected trimming when value contains escaped delimiter</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="cedricc">C&#233;dric Couralet</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 27 May 2014 06:42:38 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 27 Nov 2014 20:45:15 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>1.9</version>
                    <version>1.10</version>
                                                    <component>Type conversion</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14227960" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 27 Nov 2014 20:45:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;First of all, sorry that it took so long to get back to this!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am not sure about the best way to deal with this. I assume the reason for this trimming is to handle whitespace around the delimiter character. If you have a property declaration like&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;tt&gt;key = value1, value2, value3 ,value4&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
you typically do not want the spaces before or after the delimiter to be part of the values.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We could try to be smart and only trim values in the middle of the list, leaving out the first and the last value. But I guess, in general it is not possible to decide what a specific application wants. So should we make trimming more configurable? In version 2.0, there is a new class &lt;tt&gt;DefaultListDelimiterHandler&lt;/tt&gt; which is responsible for list delimiter splitting. This class could be initialized with a &lt;em&gt;trimMode&lt;/em&gt; and then apply different algorithms.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-573] The values of XML configuration keys having namespace prefix are null</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-573</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Consider such snippet:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testElementWithNameSpace() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; xml =
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&amp;lt;Config&amp;gt;\n&quot;&lt;/span&gt; +
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&amp;lt;dsig:Transforms xmlns:dsig=\&quot;&lt;/span&gt;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#\&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&amp;gt;\n&quot;&lt;/span&gt; +
&lt;/span&gt;            &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;  &amp;lt;dsig:Transform Algorithm=\&quot;&lt;/span&gt;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.w3.org/TR/1999/REC-xpath-19991116\&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&amp;gt;\n&quot;&lt;/span&gt; +
&lt;/span&gt;            &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;    &amp;lt;dsig:XPath xmlns:ietf=\&quot;&lt;/span&gt;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.ietf.org\&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot; xmlns:pl=\&quot;&lt;/span&gt;http://test.test\&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&amp;gt;self::pl:policy1&amp;lt;/dsig:XPath&amp;gt;\n&quot;&lt;/span&gt; +
&lt;/span&gt;            &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;  &amp;lt;/dsig:Transform&amp;gt;\n&quot;&lt;/span&gt; +
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;  &amp;lt;dsig:Transform Algorithm=\&quot;&lt;/span&gt;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.w3.org/TR/2001/REC-xml-c14n-20010315\&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/&amp;gt;\n&quot;&lt;/span&gt; +
&lt;/span&gt;            &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&amp;lt;/dsig:Transforms&amp;gt;&quot;&lt;/span&gt; +
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&amp;lt;/Config&amp;gt;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; XMLConfiguration config = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; XMLConfiguration();
    config.setAttributeSplittingDisabled(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;);
    config.setDelimiterParsingDisabled(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;);
    config.setExpressionEngine(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; XPathExpressionEngine());

    config.load(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; StringReader(xml));
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(ConfigurationUtils.toString(config));
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;It prints all keys as null:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;dsig:Transforms/dsig:Transform/dsig:XPath=&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
dsig:Transforms/dsig:Transform/dsig:XPath/@xmlns:ietf=&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
dsig:Transforms/dsig:Transform/dsig:XPath/@xmlns:pl=&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
dsig:Transforms/dsig:Transform/@Algorithm=&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
dsig:Transforms/@xmlns:dsig=&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Without XPathExpressionEngine set it prints correct values:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;dsig:Transforms.dsig:Transform.dsig:XPath=self::pl:policy1
dsig:Transforms.dsig:Transform.dsig:XPath[@xmlns:ietf]=http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.ietf.org
&lt;/span&gt;dsig:Transforms.dsig:Transform.dsig:XPath[@xmlns:pl]=http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//test.test
&lt;/span&gt;dsig:Transforms.dsig:Transform[@Algorithm]=[http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.w3.org/TR/1999/REC-xpath-19991116, http://www.w3.org/TR/2001/REC-xml-c14n-20010315]
&lt;/span&gt;dsig:Transforms[@xmlns:dsig]=http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;JXPath 1.3 version dependecy was used.&lt;br/&gt;
Am I missing something?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12706381">CONFIGURATION-573</key>
            <summary>The values of XML configuration keys having namespace prefix are null</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13982077" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 26 Apr 2014 19:16:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;First of all, sorry for the slow response.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Support for XML namespaces is pretty limited currently, but I was not aware that it is completely broken when using &lt;tt&gt;XPathExpressionEngine&lt;/tt&gt;. I will have a look what is going on.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the report.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-572] Possible memory leak when using CombinedConfiguration</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-572</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;We altered our code to use CombinedConfiguration in a more dynamic way and immediately started to see large memory usage. Looking for a potential leak, we realised we were missing a clear() when the config objects were done with.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Even with this call in, the leak persisted. It seems that whilst the clear() method cleans up the object, it doesn&apos;t clear the listener list as well. This leaves around stale references which then never become GC.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Will attach the patch we found worked at curing this&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12706137">CONFIGURATION-572</key>
            <summary>Possible memory leak when using CombinedConfiguration</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="walkerr">Rob Walker</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
