<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-509] Maven central maven-metadata.xml contains only a small subset of available versions</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-509</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When Maven tries to find out the available versions of commons-configuration on Maven central it downloads &lt;a href=&quot;http://repo1.maven.org/maven2//commons-configuration/commons-configuration/maven-metadata.xml&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://repo1.maven.org/maven2//commons-configuration/commons-configuration/maven-metadata.xml&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Problem is that this file does only contain a subset of available versions:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;&amp;lt;metadata modelVersion=&quot;1.1.0&quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;groupId&amp;gt;commons-configuration&amp;lt;/groupId&amp;gt;&amp;lt;artifactId&amp;gt;commons-configuration&amp;lt;/artifactId&amp;gt;&amp;lt;versioning&amp;gt;&amp;lt;latest&amp;gt;1.9&amp;lt;/latest&amp;gt;&amp;lt;release&amp;gt;1.9&amp;lt;/release&amp;gt;&amp;lt;versions&amp;gt;&amp;lt;version&amp;gt;1.7&amp;lt;/version&amp;gt;&amp;lt;version&amp;gt;1.8&amp;lt;/version&amp;gt;&amp;lt;version&amp;gt;1.9&amp;lt;/version&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/versions&amp;gt;&amp;lt;lastUpdated&amp;gt;20120821191916&amp;lt;/lastUpdated&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/versioning&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/metadata&amp;gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So in our case Maven thinks 1.6 is not available on Maven central and does not download it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Our build fails. We are not able to build.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please correct the list of versions on Maven central in the above maven-metadata.xml.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12608972">CONFIGURATION-509</key>
            <summary>Maven central maven-metadata.xml contains only a small subset of available versions</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="maik.ebert">Maik Ebert</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>maven</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 25 Sep 2012 06:26:02 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 5 Nov 2012 18:47:54 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 19 Oct 2012 19:43:40 +0000</resolved>
                                                                    <component>Build</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13463166" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Tue, 25 Sep 2012 20:06:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Do we have a Maven hero on this list who knows a solution directly or should I ask on repository@?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Out of curiosity: Is there a specific reason why you stick to version 1.6? Meanwhile 1.9 is available which is binary compatible and should contain lots of improvements and bug fixes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13480307" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 19 Oct 2012 19:43:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks to infra this issue has been fixed now. The metadata file in Maven central now again contains all released versions.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the report.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-504] HierarchicalConfiguration clear() method doesn&apos;t remove the node from its parent anymore in XML source</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-504</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Using an XML source file, I used to call HierarchicalConfiguration.clear() on an object to remove it from its parent. Now, it just clear the text and the subnodes, but not the node itself, nor its own attribute, when the file is saved.&lt;br/&gt;
Here is the code that works :&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;ConfigurationNode oldNode = configuration.getRootNode();
oldNode.getParentNode().removeChild(oldNode);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;configuration belong to a list of HierarchicalConfiguration that I obtained from configurationsAt. I didn&apos;t see any other way to remove a node I got from that method, without explicit casting to SubnodeConfiguration.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12604223">CONFIGURATION-504</key>
            <summary>HierarchicalConfiguration clear() method doesn&apos;t remove the node from its parent anymore in XML source</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="oheger">Oliver Heger</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="adrien.clerc">Adrien CLERC</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 21 Aug 2012 14:18:46 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:20:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 21 Sep 2012 19:13:10 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.8</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13439779" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 22 Aug 2012 19:24:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Just to make sure I understand your problem correctly: You have a hierarchical configuration and call &lt;tt&gt;configurationAt(key)&lt;/tt&gt; with some key to obtain a sub configuration. Then on this sub configuration you invoke &lt;tt&gt;clear()&lt;/tt&gt;. Now your expected result is that the whole node with the given key is removed from the original hierarchical configuration, right?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13440082" author="adrien.clerc" created="Thu, 23 Aug 2012 06:31:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s quite like this. In fact, I call &lt;tt&gt;configurationsAt(key)&lt;/tt&gt;, so I get a &lt;tt&gt;List&amp;lt;HierarchicalConfiguration&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt; (whose elements are in fact &lt;tt&gt;SubnodeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;, but I can&apos;t rely on that).&lt;br/&gt;
I then iterate on each element to perform some attribute manipulations, and on some elements of that list, I&apos;d like to remove them completely from the complete configuration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I used to call &lt;tt&gt;clear()&lt;/tt&gt; for that, but it seems that the behavior has changed since 1.8.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I hope I&apos;m clearer now &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13450008" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 6 Sep 2012 20:14:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hm, I am not sure which change in 1.8 could be responsible that the &lt;tt&gt;clear()&lt;/tt&gt; method now behaves differently.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It would be possible to change &lt;tt&gt;SubnodeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; so that its &lt;tt&gt;clear()&lt;/tt&gt; method clears the parent node in the parent configuration. Then the subnode configuration is actually detached. I just wonder what should happen if you later add new properties to the subnode configuration. They would then no longer be added to the parent configuration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Do you know what the behavior was in this case in version 1.7?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13451859" author="adrien.clerc" created="Mon, 10 Sep 2012 10:02:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is indeed a good question. Since I was only destroying nodes, I didn&apos;t test this behavior in 1.7, if you add new properties in a detached &lt;tt&gt;SubnodeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I think that&apos;s it&apos;s up to the developer to know (or to test) if the current node is actually detached or not. If you add properties inside the subnode after it has been detached, then nothing should happened inside the main configuration.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13456054" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 14 Sep 2012 19:24:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is really a hard one. I don&apos;t know what would be the best solution. No matter how it is implemented, one use case - either clearing or adding properties - seems to be broken.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I also spotted that &lt;tt&gt;SubnodeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; has some threading issues. Maybe we have to rework it in version 2.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13456853" author="adrien.clerc" created="Mon, 17 Sep 2012 07:22:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Maybe the &lt;tt&gt;clear()&lt;/tt&gt; method should stay as it is now, with an explicit mention on its exact behavior in the documentation.&lt;br/&gt;
For the old behavior, it should be better to create a &lt;tt&gt;remove()&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;removeFromParent()&lt;/tt&gt; method that will be more explicit on its purpose.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What do you think of this?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13458083" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Tue, 18 Sep 2012 19:49:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree, this sounds like a good compromise. I guess we will then have to change the &lt;tt&gt;configurationAt()&lt;/tt&gt; and &lt;tt&gt;configurationsAt()&lt;/tt&gt; methods to return &lt;tt&gt;SubnodeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; objects rather than &lt;tt&gt;HierarchicalConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; so that you do not have to do a manual cast. But this should not be a problem.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13458461" author="adrien.clerc" created="Wed, 19 Sep 2012 06:48:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;That sounds good &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; I&apos;m happy that this difficult problem will find a solution!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13460728" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 21 Sep 2012 19:13:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A new method &lt;tt&gt;clearAndDetachFromParent()&lt;/tt&gt; was added to &lt;tt&gt;SubnodeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;. The return value of &lt;tt&gt;HierarchicalConfiguration.configurationsAt()&lt;/tt&gt; was changed to a List of type &lt;tt&gt;SubnodeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fixed in subversion in revision 1388626.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13461636" author="adrien.clerc" created="Mon, 24 Sep 2012 07:10:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Many thanks for that!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-501] XMLPropertyListConfiguration swallows exceptions about invalid date properties</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-501</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;XMLPropertyListConfiguration.PListNode&lt;/tt&gt; in its &lt;tt&gt;setDateValue()&lt;/tt&gt; method just ignores parsing exceptions caused by invalid date property values. The values are not added to the newly created configuration object.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It makes sense that parsing is robust and error-tolerant. However, rather than simply swallowing exceptions, there should at least be a log output, so that users have a chance to determine that something went wrong during loading of a configuration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maybe we can later add a strict mode which fails on loading configuration files with invalid properties.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12600711">CONFIGURATION-501</key>
            <summary>XMLPropertyListConfiguration swallows exceptions about invalid date properties</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="oheger">Oliver Heger</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="oheger">Oliver Heger</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 30 Jul 2012 19:52:32 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 18:07:22 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 30 Jul 2012 20:02:13 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.8</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.9</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13425171" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 30 Jul 2012 20:02:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in revision 1367253.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310222" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:timeinstatus">
                        <customfieldname>Time in Status</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                            </customfields>
    </item>


<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-497] PropertiesConfiguration.setProperty() with auto-save returns before file handle is closed</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-497</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have an application which stores some counters in a PropertiesConfiguration with auto-save enabled. These counters are incremented regularly - during peak load the PropertiesConfiguration object will be updated every 5 milliseconds on average, and there will also be threads reading from it at the same time. All access to the PropertiesConfiguration is made through a wrapper class which enforces synchronization.&lt;br/&gt;
About one in every 8,000 calls to setProperty() will fail, seemingly because the file handle is still open from the previous call. I have a single-threaded test case which can reproduce this by writing continuously to a PropertiesConfiguration object - it usually fails within 10,000 iterations and has never successfully completed 500,000 iterations.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Test Case&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testHeavyLoadWritingToConf() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; ConfigurationException {
    PropertiesConfiguration conf = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; PropertiesConfiguration(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; java.io.File(FILE_PATH));
    conf.setAutoSave(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;);
    
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; i = 0; i &amp;lt; NUM_WRITES; i++) {
      &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (i % 100 == 0 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; i &amp;gt; 0) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Test has completed &quot;&lt;/span&gt; + i + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot; iterations&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
      }
      conf.setProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;my.counter&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, i);
    }
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;All writes successful&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
  }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stack trace&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;org.apache.commons.configuration.ConfigurationRuntimeException: Failed to auto-save
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.possiblySave(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:753)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.clearProperty(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:799)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.setProperty(AbstractConfiguration.java:485)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.setProperty(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:788)
	at com.magicmemories.spike.PersistenceLockingTest.testHeavyLoadWritingToConf(PersistenceLockingTest.java:27)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
	at junit.framework.TestCase.runTest(TestCase.java:168)
	at junit.framework.TestCase.runBare(TestCase.java:134)
	at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:110)
	at junit.framework.TestResult.runProtected(TestResult.java:128)
	at junit.framework.TestResult.run(TestResult.java:113)
	at junit.framework.TestCase.run(TestCase.java:124)
	at junit.framework.TestSuite.runTest(TestSuite.java:232)
	at junit.framework.TestSuite.run(TestSuite.java:227)
	at org.junit.internal.runners.JUnit38ClassRunner.run(JUnit38ClassRunner.java:79)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit4.runner.JUnit4TestReference.run(JUnit4TestReference.java:50)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.TestExecution.run(TestExecution.java:38)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRunner.java:467)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRunner.java:683)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run(RemoteTestRunner.java:390)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main(RemoteTestRunner.java:197)
Caused by: org.apache.commons.configuration.ConfigurationException: Unable to save to file C:\testarea\test.properties
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.DefaultFileSystem.getOutputStream(DefaultFileSystem.java:139)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.DefaultFileSystem.getOutputStream(DefaultFileSystem.java:95)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.save(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:473)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.save(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:414)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.possiblySave(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:749)
	... 23 more
Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: C:\testarea\test.properties (The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another process)
	at java.io.FileOutputStream.open(Native Method)

	at java.io.FileOutputStream.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(FileOutputStream.java:145)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.DefaultFileSystem.getOutputStream(DefaultFileSystem.java:135)
	... 27 more
&lt;/pre&gt;

        <key id="12555044">CONFIGURATION-497</key>
            <summary>PropertiesConfiguration.setProperty() with auto-save returns before file handle is closed</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>

                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 13 May 2012 01:38:58 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 May 2012 06:23:45 +0000</updated>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13276179" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Tue, 15 May 2012 20:15:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Many thanks for this detailed report.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I had a look at the code, and this issue is indeed interesting: From your stacktrace, it is obvious that the &lt;tt&gt;AbstractFileConfiguration.save(URL)&lt;/tt&gt; method is called. This method opens an output stream and closes it at the end in a finally block. So this seems to be alright.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, &lt;tt&gt;save(URL)&lt;/tt&gt; delegates to &lt;tt&gt;save(OutputStream)&lt;/tt&gt;, and here something suspicious happens. A &lt;tt&gt;FileWriter&lt;/tt&gt; is created on top of the output stream and used to write the content of the configuration. This writer is never closed - only its underlying output stream.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have no clue whether this can cause the problem; will have to do some tests. OTOH, this is the only strange thing related to resource handling I found. On which platform did you see this exception? Did you test on other platforms, too?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13277274" author="mmkate" created="Wed, 16 May 2012 23:57:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve seen this on 4 different PCs so far (3x Win7 and 1x WinXP) with various updates of Java 1.6 from 23 through to 30. Our nightly build runs on a Linux box and so far it doesn&apos;t seem to have happened there.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13279823" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 20 May 2012 17:41:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, I cannot reproduce the problem on my machine (Win 7). The test runs successfully. Maybe my old laptop is too slow? This makes it hard to fix.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I can try to create a patch which uses a different approach for creating the writer and ensures that it gets closed. IMO this is the only strange thing in the code which could cause this behavior. Would you be able to test this? If this actually solves the problem, we can add it to the code base.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13279827" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 20 May 2012 17:53:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch to ensure that the Writer is always closed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13282227" author="mmkate" created="Thu, 24 May 2012 06:19:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Nope, that patch did not fix it.&lt;br/&gt;
And that was when I noticed that my real-time virus scanning had somehow magicly turned itself back on even though I always keep it turned off in my development environment. The test case is passing now, so the real problem is more likely to be a bug in my synchronized wrapper.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for your time Oliver, sorry to have led you up the garden path!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-496] Excessive Synchronization AbstractFileConfiguration</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-496</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;We are having a problem with commons configuration 1.6 AbstractFileConfiguration &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;During a stress test we are seeing that we have wait locks against this method causing this method not to complete for up to one second.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We are using the FileReloadStrategy delegate which makes a check on the file system when now + interval is greater than the compare time.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Why can&apos;t we make this check before the synchronized block thus increasing throughput. I have noticed in 1.8 that the caller to this method is synchronized. This seems like excessive synchronization. Any ideas how to solve this. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void reload()
    {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;synchronized&lt;/span&gt; (reloadLock)
        {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (noReload == 0)
            {
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt;
                {
                    enterNoReload(); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// avoid reentrant calls
&lt;/span&gt;
                    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (strategy.reloadingRequired())
                    {
                        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (getLogger().isInfoEnabled())
                        {
                            getLogger().info(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Reloading configuration. URL is &quot;&lt;/span&gt; + getURL());
                        }
                        fireEvent(EVENT_RELOAD, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, getURL(), &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;);
                        setDetailEvents(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;);
                        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; autoSaveBak = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt;.isAutoSave(); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// save the current state
&lt;/span&gt;                        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt;.setAutoSave(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// deactivate autoSave to prevent information loss
&lt;/span&gt;                        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt;
                        {
                            clear();
                            load();
                        }
                        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;finally&lt;/span&gt;
                        {
                            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt;.setAutoSave(autoSaveBak); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// set autoSave to previous value
&lt;/span&gt;                            setDetailEvents(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;);
                        }
                        fireEvent(EVENT_RELOAD, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, getURL(), &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;);

                        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// notify the strategy
&lt;/span&gt;                        strategy.reloadingPerformed();
                    }
                }
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;catch&lt;/span&gt; (Exception e)
                {
                    fireError(EVENT_RELOAD, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, e);
                    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// todo rollback the changes &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; the file can&apos;t be reloaded
&lt;/span&gt;                }
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;finally&lt;/span&gt;
                {
                    exitNoReload();
                }
            }
        }
    }

&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12554374">CONFIGURATION-496</key>
            <summary>Excessive Synchronization AbstractFileConfiguration</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="indianbishop">Tim Canavan</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 8 May 2012 19:51:13 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:20:52 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 3 Jun 2013 20:34:46 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.6</version>
                    <version>1.7</version>
                    <version>1.8</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>File reloading</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13270831" author="ralph.goers@dslextreme.com" created="Tue, 8 May 2012 21:06:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There is no simple answer to your question. Commons Configuration used to not be thread-safe. Unfortunately, I discovered that after our application was already in production. My use case deals with DefaultConfigurationBuilder constructing DynamicCombinedConfigurations and XMLConfigurations all with file reloading.  Due to the way CombinedConfigurations work every time a configuration file was reloaded other configurations that shared the common file were corrupted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, you can&apos;t check to see if a reload is required without holding the lock or multiple threads will end up performing the reload. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;All of this was put into place while the minimum version was Java 1.4. Now that it is Java 5 much of this code can be redone to take advantage of java.util.concurrent. I just haven&apos;t gotten to it. However, I&apos;ve had reports of similar issues from my users so I plan to  address these issues in the very near future.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13673521" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 3 Jun 2013 20:33:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In version 2.0 reloading and synchronized access to configurations have been completely redesigned. A so-called &lt;tt&gt;Synchronizer&lt;/tt&gt; is now used to control concurrent access to a configuration. While the default synchronizer is just a dummy, applications can change it according to their use cases. There is also an implementation of &lt;tt&gt;Synchronizer&lt;/tt&gt; based on the JDK&apos;s &lt;tt&gt;ReentrantReadWriteLock&lt;/tt&gt; class.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BTW, the &lt;tt&gt;AbstractFileConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; class no longer exists. &lt;em&gt;Configuration builders&lt;/em&gt; are now responsible for creating and loading configurations. Reloading is also handled by these builders.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-495] If delimiter parsing is disabled, adding of list properties to an AbstractConfiguration does not work correctly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-495</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When calling addProperty() or setProperty() with a collection or an array as value it is expected that the single elements are added rather than the container. However, if delimiter parsing is disabled, this check is not performed, and the complex value is directly added. This causes strange effects, for instance when the configuration is saved: then the complex value is just converted to a string. Loading the same configuration again will then produce different values for those properties.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12552720">CONFIGURATION-495</key>
            <summary>If delimiter parsing is disabled, adding of list properties to an AbstractConfiguration does not work correctly</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="oheger">Oliver Heger</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 25 Apr 2012 20:14:15 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 18:07:22 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 26 Apr 2012 06:13:50 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.8</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.9</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13262397" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 26 Apr 2012 06:10:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;After some research I figured out that only the method HierarchicalConfiguration.setProperty() is affected. It does not handle lists or arrays correctly if delimiter parsing is disabled. The addProperty() method and the setProperty() method defined by AbstractConfiguration work as expected.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13262399" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 26 Apr 2012 06:13:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in subversion in revision 1330666.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-493] Incorrect backslash handling in windows environment variable</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-493</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Windows environment variable :&lt;br/&gt;
DFSROOT=\\DFSROOT\BEG&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Properties file :&lt;br/&gt;
Personnel.jdbc.url = jdbc:odbc:Driver=&lt;/p&gt;
{Microsoft Access Driver (*.mdb)};DBQ=${DFSROOT}/databases/personnel.mdb&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
Value returned...&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
...using 1.8 (incorrect) :&lt;br/&gt;
jdbc:odbc:Driver={Microsoft Access Driver (*.mdb)}
&lt;p&gt;;DBQ=\DFSROOT\BEG/databases/personnel.mdb&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;...using 1.7 (correct) :&lt;br/&gt;
jdbc:odbc:Driver=&lt;/p&gt;
{Microsoft Access Driver (*.mdb)}
&lt;p&gt;;DBQ=\\DFSROOT\BEG/databases/personnel.mdb&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12550673">CONFIGURATION-493</key>
            <summary>Incorrect backslash handling in windows environment variable</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                            <comment id="13252648" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 12 Apr 2012 17:43:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The changes you see may be related to &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-418&quot; title=&quot;incorrect backslash parsing&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;CONFIGURATION-418&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;CONFIGURATION-418&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. (This issue also contains a longer discussion about backslash parsing and its complexity.) It may be necessary now to escape the backslashes in the value of the variable. Details can be found in the user&apos;s guide at &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/configuration/userguide/howto_properties.html#Special_Characters_and_Escaping&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/configuration/userguide/howto_properties.html#Special_Characters_and_Escaping&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-492] XMLConfiguration.getStringArray does not parse OS Environment Variables</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-492</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When using a OS environment variable in an XMLConfiguration file, the getStringArray() method does not correctly parse multiple items in the same entry.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;XML:&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;items&amp;gt;{$env:items}&amp;lt;/items&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Windows Environment variable %items% is set to &quot;item1,item2&quot;. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Code:&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;br/&gt;
String[] items = config.getStringArray(&quot;items&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
for (Sting item : items) {&lt;br/&gt;
  System.out.println(&quot;Item: &quot; + item);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Output:&lt;br/&gt;
Item: item1,item2&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows XP, Commons Configuration 1.8&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12547406">CONFIGURATION-492</key>
            <summary>XMLConfiguration.getStringArray does not parse OS Environment Variables</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="cjjackson">Chris Jackson</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 21 Mar 2012 16:14:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:12:56 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>1.8</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.x</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Interpolation</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13241401" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 29 Mar 2012 17:20:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In the current implementation list splitting is not done on substituted variable values. This is true for all methods supporting variables, including &lt;tt&gt;getStringArray()&lt;/tt&gt;, &lt;tt&gt;getList()&lt;/tt&gt; or the get methods for simple data types.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am not sure whether we should change this. It would probably make the implementation more complex. In addition, it may cause constellations which are hard to diagnose. For instance, if &lt;tt&gt;getString()&lt;/tt&gt; is called on a property with a variable which contains multiple items, should then only the first item be returned?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Well, the documentation does not explicitly mention that the list delimiter in variable values is not taken into account. So at least this could be improved.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-491] XMLConfiguration.XMLBuilderVisitor.listDelimiter initial value is always overridden</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-491</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The private class field XMLConfiguration.XMLBuilderVisitor.listDelimiter is initialised to&lt;br/&gt;
AbstractConfiguration.getDefaultListDelimiter();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, the only constructor overwrites the field.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So the default init could be removed, and the field could be made final.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12546917">CONFIGURATION-491</key>
            <summary>XMLConfiguration.XMLBuilderVisitor.listDelimiter initial value is always overridden</summary>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-490] DefaultConfigurationKey.setExpressionEngine - non-final method called by constructor</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-490</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If a constructor calls an overrideable method, sub-classes that override the method can cause failures&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12546914">CONFIGURATION-490</key>
            <summary>DefaultConfigurationKey.setExpressionEngine - non-final method called by constructor</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 17 Mar 2012 18:49:48 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:12:56 +0000</updated>
                                                            <fixVersion>2.x</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13232040" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 18:51:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;NodeAddData ctor has the same problem&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232045" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 19:04:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;ConfigurationFactory as well&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232047" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 19:07:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Also:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ConfigurationXMLReader()&lt;br/&gt;
DefaultConfigurationBuilder&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are probably lots more&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232057" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 19:52:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is similar to the problem reported in &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-431&quot; title=&quot;Code caused NullPointer error in XMLConfiguration&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;CONFIGURATION-431&quot;&gt;CONFIGURATION-431&lt;/a&gt; (IIUC).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14084012" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 3 Aug 2014 15:36:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;All the classes mentioned in this ticket have been either reworked or removed in the redesign towards version 2.0.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In the classes I reworked for 2.0 I tried to keep an eye on this problem, but there may be still candidates I have missed. And there are still other classes that have not been touched during this refactoring.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So how do we proceed with this ticket? Should it be closed or do you want to do another review of the code base (which would be highly appreciated)?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14084545" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 4 Aug 2014 11:21:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t think the ticket should be closed until all the instances have been fixed.&lt;br/&gt;
Have you tried running FindBugs on the code? IIRC it can detect many of these issues.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If I find time I will have another look at the code.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14085131" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 4 Aug 2014 19:14:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A FindBugs report is created as part of the site build:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/findbugs.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/findbugs.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, this special problem is not detected - at least not by the standard configuration. I don&apos;t know whether this could be tweaked.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14086460" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 5 Aug 2014 16:29:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The Findbugs report is says Effort: minimum&lt;br/&gt;
Also the Findbugs plugin is out of date.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Ideally the Findbugs version and config should be defined as properties in the pom, and then used in &amp;lt;plugin&amp;gt; sections for both &amp;lt;build&amp;gt; and &amp;lt;reporting&amp;gt; sections so the plugin can be run using the command line and as part of the site build (which takes longer).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-487] DataConfiguration.get() cannot handle a trivial conversion</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-487</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A call to &lt;tt&gt;DataConfiguration.get()&lt;/tt&gt; eventually invokes the &lt;tt&gt;PropertyConverter.to()&lt;/tt&gt; method. Here a number of supported data types are checked and corresponding conversions are done.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, the case that the value does not need to be converted at all - because it already has the expected type - is not taken into account. This is especially a problem for string values: there is not conversion to string, so the get() method fails even if the value is already a string.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12546907">CONFIGURATION-487</key>
            <summary>DataConfiguration.get() cannot handle a trivial conversion</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="oheger">Oliver Heger</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="oheger">Oliver Heger</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 17 Mar 2012 17:03:03 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 18:07:22 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 17 Mar 2012 20:11:31 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.8</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.9</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Type conversion</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-486] BeanHelper.setDefaultBeanFactory() is thread-hostile and not thread-safe</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-486</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;BeanHelper.setDefaultBeanFactory() sets a private static field.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is thread-hostile, because different threads cannot safely use different factories.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s also not thread-safe, as the variable is not guaranteed to be published safely.&lt;br/&gt;
Should either make the variable volatile, or synchronize both getter and setter.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12546490">CONFIGURATION-486</key>
            <summary>BeanHelper.setDefaultBeanFactory() is thread-hostile and not thread-safe</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 14 Mar 2012 22:17:44 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:20:55 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 6 Jan 2014 17:13:49 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13232009" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 16:51:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed. Do you want to go ahead and fix this?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232022" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 17:21:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixing the thread-safety issue is trivial.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, the class will still be potentially thread-hostile, depending on when the setter and getter are used.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fixing that might require a redesign of the code.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232043" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 18:58:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Same problem with AbstractConfiguration.defaultListDelimiter &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232048" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 19:10:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;ALso FileSystem.fileSystem&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232049" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 19:13:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;HierarchicalConfiguration.defaultExpressionEngine&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="13232063" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 20:14:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, the library was designed initially without thread-safety in mind &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; I think, this should be an important topic for version 2.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13760549" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 6 Sep 2013 19:41:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created a specific issue for dealing with &lt;tt&gt;BeanHelper&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13863117" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 6 Jan 2014 17:13:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;All points mentioned in this ticket have now been addressed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Default values are no longer set using static member fields; alternatives have been created.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                <issuelinks>
                            <issuelinktype id="10030">
                    <name>Reference</name>
                                                                <inwardlinks description="is related to">
                                        <issuelink>
            <issuekey id="12667382">CONFIGURATION-554</issuekey>
        </issuelink>
                            </inwardlinks>
                                    </issuelinktype>
                    </issuelinks>
                <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-484] HierarchicalINIConfiguration don&apos;t encode coma separated lists/arrays </title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-484</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;HierarchicalINIConfiguration correctely parses coma separated values into arrays or lists. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However there is no way to save arrays/lists in this format. It always split the list in a bunch of properties. &lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows x64&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12545409">CONFIGURATION-484</key>
            <summary>HierarchicalINIConfiguration don&apos;t encode coma separated lists/arrays </summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>

                            <comment id="13232064" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 20:21:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Well, then this issue is probably not too critical. I am afraid that a fix would not be easy.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In &lt;tt&gt;PropertiesConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; we go a long way to retain many aspects of the original layout by using a &lt;tt&gt;PropertiesConfigurationLayout&lt;/tt&gt; object. I wonder whether parts of this approach could be reused here; at least properties like comments, separators, or leading blanc lines are common for boths formats.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

            <title>[CONFIGURATION-483] DatabaseConfiguration unclosed resultset</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-483</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;An error ocurred when invoking method DatabaseConfiguration.close because the resultset is not closed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ERROR: &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;PoolConnection@19859608&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; close() : Got 1 unclosed ResultSets !&lt;br/&gt;
	uk.org.primrose.pool.core.PoolConnection.checkAndCloseResultSets(PoolConnection.java:46)&lt;br/&gt;
	uk.org.primrose.pool.core.PoolConnection.close(PoolConnection.java:133)&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.configuration.DatabaseConfiguration.close(DatabaseConfiguration.java:596)&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.configuration.DatabaseConfiguration.containsKey(DatabaseConfiguration.java:394)&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.configuration.CompositeConfiguration.getProperty(CompositeConfiguration.java:190)&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.resolveContainerStore(AbstractConfiguration.java:1160)&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.getString(AbstractConfiguration.java:1035)&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.getString(AbstractConfiguration.java:1018)&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-482] Optional dependencies are not marked optional in the manifest&apos;s Import-Package section</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-482</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following page lists the runtime dependencies based on the components. This is reflected in the pom file since many are listed as optional (e.g. commons-jexl). However, if you want to use commons-configuration in an OSGi container, those become required because the corresponding packages are listed in the manifest&apos;s Import-Package section. They do not have the &quot;resolution:=optional&quot; qualifier on it so you get an error if you do not include something like commons-jexl yourself.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/configuration/dependencies.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/configuration/dependencies.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12544540">CONFIGURATION-482</key>
            <summary>Optional dependencies are not marked optional in the manifest&apos;s Import-Package section</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="fifalover">Chris Seieroe</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 29 Feb 2012 00:38:53 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 18:07:22 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 22 May 2012 20:21:57 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.8</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.9</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Build</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>2</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13219564" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 29 Feb 2012 21:20:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The generation of the manifest is done by the maven bundle plug-in. It would be cool if this plug-in could evaluate the optional tags automatically.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13222182" author="fifalover" created="Mon, 5 Mar 2012 06:41:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like it already does as of version 2.3.4. If I&apos;m reading the pom files correctly, commons-config 1.8 uses version 2.3.5. At least that&apos;s what I see in commons-parent version 23.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX-954&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX-954&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX-2809&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX-2809&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13227912" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 12 Mar 2012 21:14:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hm, you are right. Then I wonder why it does not work as expected. Is a special configuration required? I will have to study the plug-in documentation. Any hints are welcome!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13262885" author="fifalover" created="Thu, 26 Apr 2012 19:05:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Perhaps there&apos;s a bug with maven-bundle-plugin that doesn&apos;t automatically add optional in this case. As a workaround, I added the following property to the pom.xml file and forced &quot;resolution:=optional&quot; on those optional dependencies. That seemed to do the trick.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;commons.osgi.import&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.beanutils.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.digester.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.collections.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.codec.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.jxpath.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.xml.resolver.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	javax.servlet.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.jexl2.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	org.apache.commons.vfs2.*;resolution:=optional,&lt;br/&gt;
	*&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/commons.osgi.import&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13279881" author="topping" created="Sun, 20 May 2012 22:05:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is kind of treacherous because jxpath has it&apos;s own set of rather undesirable dependencies that need to get pulled in for closure on the otherwise optional / unnecessary jxpath dep.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Oliver, what can we do to help you set a fix version on this?  &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13280406" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 21 May 2012 19:33:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Brian, thanks for your offer. I think the solution suggested by Chris - explicitly stating all optional packages - is the way to go. I will add this to the pom soon.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13281189" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Tue, 22 May 2012 20:21:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in subversion in revision 1341612. The property suggested by Chris was added to the pom. Many thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-481] Variable interpolation across files broken in 1.7 &amp; 1.8</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-481</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;With Commons Configuration 1.6, I was able to declare a variable in a properties file, and then reference it in a XML file using the ${myvar} syntax.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;global.properties:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;myvar=abc&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;test.xml:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-xml&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;products&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;product name=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;abc&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;desc&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;${myvar}-product&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/desc&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/product&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/products&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;config.xml:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-xml&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;properties fileName=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;global.properties&quot;&lt;/span&gt;/&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;xml fileName=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test.xml&quot;&lt;/span&gt; config-name=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;expressionEngine config-class=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;org.apache.commons.configuration.tree.xpath.XPathExpressionEngine&quot;&lt;/span&gt;/&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/xml&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When I try to retrieve the value, like so:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;combinedConfig.getConfiguration(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).configurationAt(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;products/product[@name=&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;abc&apos;&lt;/span&gt;]&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;).getString(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;desc&quot;&lt;/span&gt;)&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I get &quot;${myvar}-product&quot; instead of &quot;abc-product&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This was working in Commons Configuration 1.6, but seems to be broken in 1.7 and 1.8.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Any OS, but have verified with Windows 7 and AIX 6.1, running Java 1.6.0.&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12544193">CONFIGURATION-481</key>
            <summary>Variable interpolation across files broken in 1.7 &amp; 1.8</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="oheger">Oliver Heger</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dprantzalos">Jim Prantzalos</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 26 Feb 2012 20:27:46 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 18:07:22 +0000</updated>

                                    <version>1.7</version>
                    <version>1.8</version>

                            <comment id="13216838" author="dprantzalos" created="Sun, 26 Feb 2012 21:02:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Added a test case that demonstrates the issue using 1.6, 1.7, and 1.8.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13219533" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 29 Feb 2012 20:49:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I am working on a fix (or better a re-implementation) based on the &lt;tt&gt;ConfigurationInterpolator&lt;/tt&gt; class and its feature to construct a chain of interpolators. The idea is that &lt;tt&gt;DefaultConfigurationBuilder&lt;/tt&gt; adds a special parent interpolator to the configurations it creates which queries the newly constructed &lt;tt&gt;CombinedConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I must admit it is a mystery to me how this feature could work in the past. (I also did not find any breaking change.) It was certainly an undocumented feature which only worked by acciddent.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13219555" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 29 Feb 2012 21:15:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in subversion in revision 1295276. Thanks for spotting this and the tests.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13220433" author="dprantzalos" created="Thu, 1 Mar 2012 22:30:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patched into 1.8 and rebuilt. Works great. Thank you!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
