<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-480] Reading Manifest files using PropertiesConfiguration</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-480</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve searched through the documentation and online with Google. The documentation for PropertiesConfiguration explains that it can parse files with &apos;=&apos; or &apos;:&apos; or &apos; &apos; as delimiters. I have a MANIFEST.MF file with the following format:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;MANIFEST.MF&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Manifest-Version: 1.0
Implementation-Title: webapp
Implementation-Version: 0.0.1
Created-By: Gradle 1.0-milestone-6
Build-Jdk: 1.6.0_26


&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve tried to use the PropertiesConfiguration to parse this file, assuming that the &apos; &apos; delimiter would be used to divide key-value pairs. Instead I get the following error:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Key &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; add operation must be defined!
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.tree.DefaultExpressionEngine.prepareAdd(DefaultExpressionEngine.java:420)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.HierarchicalConfiguration.addPropertyDirect(HierarchicalConfiguration.java:383)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractHierarchicalFileConfiguration.addPropertyDirect(AbstractHierarchicalFileConfiguration.java:147)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.addPropertyValues(AbstractConfiguration.java:423)
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.append(AbstractConfiguration.java:1271)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;At the moment I&apos;ve created a (very rough) custom PropertiesReader as suggested by the User Guide for handling &quot;unconventional formats&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;ManifestPropertiesReader
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;extends&lt;/span&gt; PropertiesConfiguration.PropertiesReader {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; ManifestPropertiesReader(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; Reader in, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;char&lt;/span&gt; delimiter) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;super&lt;/span&gt;(in, delimiter);
    }

    @Override
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;protected&lt;/span&gt; void parseProperty(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; line) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; pos = line.indexOf(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;:&apos;&lt;/span&gt;);
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; key = line.substring(0, pos).trim();
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; value = line.substring(pos + 1).trim();

        initPropertyName(key);
        initPropertyValue(value);
    }
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;ManifestIOFactory
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;extends&lt;/span&gt; PropertiesConfiguration.DefaultIOFactory {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;/** Use a custom {@code PropertiesReader} &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; Manifest files. */&lt;/span&gt;
    @Override
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; PropertiesReader createPropertiesReader(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; Reader in,
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;char&lt;/span&gt; delimiter) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ManifestPropertiesReader(in, delimiter);
    }
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Should all this be necessary to parse MANIFEST.MF files or have I missed something?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12543981">CONFIGURATION-480</key>
            <summary>Reading Manifest files using PropertiesConfiguration</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="novabyte">Chris Molozian</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 24 Feb 2012 11:25:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 24 Mar 2016 20:12:57 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>1.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.x</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13215884" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 24 Feb 2012 20:38:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is strange. The exception stack trace you provided seems to indicate that a hierarchical configuration is used rather than PropertiesConfiguration (which is not hierarchical). Can you post the code which tries to load the manifest file?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13217169" author="novabyte" created="Mon, 27 Feb 2012 12:37:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Apologies for the late response, I&apos;ve embedded the code that&apos;s attempting to parse the MANIFEST.MF file:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;PropertiesConfiguration manifestConf = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; PropertiesConfiguration();
manifestConf.setIOFactory(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ManifestIOFactory());
manifestConf.setFileName(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
manifestConf.load();
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You didn&apos;t really answer my other question, is there anything within Apache Commons Configuration that supports the parsing of the MANIFEST.MF format?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13217549" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 27 Feb 2012 20:55:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If your use case is just splitting key value pairs separated by a colon, then this should be possible with PropertiesConfiguration out of the box. Our unit test suite contains tests with files using the colon as alternative separator. So I have no idea why this does not work in your case. As I pointed out, the exception you posted indicates that PropertiesConfiguration is not used at all.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, manifest files can become more complex, e.g. there is a hard limit for the line length and automatic line wrapping, or a special syntax for directives or properties with multiple values intoduced by the OSGi specification. Commons Configuration does not contain a class which supports these features or is specialized on parsing manifest files.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-479] Cannot write to files within an app server directory</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-479</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This issue is really grappling me. I use  Apache commons configuration to read the configuration for my application. I expose my configuration through a jmx client so that I can change the configuration at runtime and would like to persist the changes to the original load form.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have multiple configuration sources so I use a CombinedConfiguration object to read in my config.xml file. I have wrapped custom logic and rules to save the confgiuration to the persistent store.&lt;br/&gt;
I use Jboss AS5 to deploy my application. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;All is well when I have configuration files in the filesystem outside  $JBOSS-HOME/server/default/deploy. I am able to read fine and write back to the config files fine too. &lt;br/&gt;
but the problem is when I bring in the Config files in the following directoy $JBOSS-HOME/server/default/deploy/&lt;/p&gt;
{application-name}
&lt;p&gt;/..&lt;br/&gt;
I can read the configuration fine, but when I try to write the configuration back to the persistent store using the save method of the respective configuration(like PropertiesConfiguration &amp;amp; XMLConfiguration) using a jmx client(I also tried to harcode and save within code immediatly after reading my configuration). I keep getting the follwing exception :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.net.UnknownServiceException: protocol doesn&apos;t support output&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.net.URLConnection.getOutputStream(URLConnection.java:792)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.DefaultFileSystem.getOutputStream(DefaultFileSystem.java:113)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.save(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:461)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.save(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:402)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.possiblySave(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:737)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.clearProperty(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:784)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.setProperty(AbstractConfiguration.java:483)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.setProperty(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:774)&lt;br/&gt;
        ......&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please throw some light on the exception because it is helping me nowhere in understanding the issue&lt;br/&gt;
If I am able to read it, I should also be able to save it back..but it is not happening within JBOSS directory(I can only read). Moment I shift my configurations outside that to a different place in the Filesystem say /home/../Config and also keep the config.xml(containing the reference to the Configuration sources)it is perfectly working fine.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is being a blocker for me. I may have completely misread the scenario, so please throw light on the same if I am missing anything or more details are needed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Following is the piece of code used to read the configuration :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;...&lt;br/&gt;
builder.setFile(new File(Path to CONFIG_DIRECTORY +&lt;br/&gt;
		  CONFIG_DEFINITION_FILENAME(config.xml)));&lt;br/&gt;
CombinedConfiguration combinedConfig = builder.getConfiguration(true); &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;sample config.xml file : &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;ISO-8859-1&quot;?&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;configuration&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;header /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;override&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
		&amp;lt;properties&lt;br/&gt;
			fileName=&quot;db.properties&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
			autoSave=&quot;true&quot; config-name=&quot;properties1&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;properties&lt;br/&gt;
			fileName=&quot;jms.properties&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
			autoSave=&quot;true&quot; config-name=&quot;properties2&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
		&amp;lt;properties&lt;br/&gt;
			fileName=&quot;test.xml&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
			autoSave=&quot;true&quot; config-name=&quot;properties3&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
		&amp;lt;xml fileName=&quot;gui.xml&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
			autoSave=&quot;true&quot; config-name=&quot;xml1&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;/override&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;additional /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/configuration&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Following is sample code used to write back updated values to the persistent store :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	xmlConfig = (XMLConfiguration) combinedConfig.getConfiguration(&quot;configuration source name&quot;);;&lt;br/&gt;
							if (xmlConfig.containsKey(key)) {&lt;br/&gt;
								try {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;									// Update the value.&lt;br/&gt;
									xmlConfig.setProperty(key, value);&lt;br/&gt;
									xmlConfig.save();&lt;/p&gt;

</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java , Linux, Jboss&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-478] Cannot write to files within an app server directory</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-478</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This issue is really grappling me. I use  Apache commons configuration to read the configuration for my application. I expose my configuration through a jmx client so that I can change the configuration at runtime and would like to persist the changes to the original load form.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have multiple configuration sources so I use a CombinedConfiguration object to read in my config.xml file. I have wrapped custom logic and rules to save the confgiuration to the persistent store.&lt;br/&gt;
I use Jboss AS5 to deploy my application. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;All is well when I have configuration files in the filesystem outside  $JBOSS-HOME/server/default/deploy. I am able to read fine and write back to the config files fine too. &lt;br/&gt;
but the problem is when I bring in the Config files in the following directoy $JBOSS-HOME/server/default/deploy/&lt;/p&gt;
{application-name}
&lt;p&gt;/..&lt;br/&gt;
I can read the configuration fine, but when I try to write the configuration back to the persistent store using the save method of the respective configuration(like PropertiesConfiguration &amp;amp; XMLConfiguration) using a jmx client(I also tried to harcode and save within code immediatly after reading my configuration). I keep getting the follwing exception :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.net.UnknownServiceException: protocol doesn&apos;t support output&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.net.URLConnection.getOutputStream(URLConnection.java:792)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.DefaultFileSystem.getOutputStream(DefaultFileSystem.java:113)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.save(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:461)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.save(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:402)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.possiblySave(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:737)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.clearProperty(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:784)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.setProperty(AbstractConfiguration.java:483)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractFileConfiguration.setProperty(AbstractFileConfiguration.java:774)&lt;br/&gt;
        ......&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please throw some light on the exception because it is helping me nowhere in understanding the issue&lt;br/&gt;
If I am able to read it, I should also be able to save it back..but it is not happening within JBOSS directory(I can only read). Moment I shift my configurations outside that to a different place in the Filesystem say /home/../Config and also keep the config.xml(containing the reference to the Configuration sources)it is perfectly working fine.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is being a blocker for me. I may have completely misread the scenario, so please throw light on the same if I am missing anything or more details are needed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Following is the piece of code used to read the configuration :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;...&lt;br/&gt;
builder.setFile(new File(Path to CONFIG_DIRECTORY +&lt;br/&gt;
		  CONFIG_DEFINITION_FILENAME(config.xml)));&lt;br/&gt;
CombinedConfiguration combinedConfig = builder.getConfiguration(true); &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;sample config.xml file : &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;ISO-8859-1&quot;?&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;configuration&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;header /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;override&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
		&amp;lt;properties&lt;br/&gt;
			fileName=&quot;db.properties&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
			autoSave=&quot;true&quot; config-name=&quot;properties1&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;properties&lt;br/&gt;
			fileName=&quot;jms.properties&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
			autoSave=&quot;true&quot; config-name=&quot;properties2&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
		&amp;lt;properties&lt;br/&gt;
			fileName=&quot;test.xml&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
			autoSave=&quot;true&quot; config-name=&quot;properties3&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
		&amp;lt;xml fileName=&quot;gui.xml&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
			autoSave=&quot;true&quot; config-name=&quot;xml1&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;/override&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
	&amp;lt;additional /&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/configuration&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Following is sample code used to write back updated values to the persistent store :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	xmlConfig = (XMLConfiguration) combinedConfig.getConfiguration(&quot;configuration source name&quot;);;&lt;br/&gt;
							if (xmlConfig.containsKey(key)) {&lt;br/&gt;
								try {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;									// Update the value.&lt;br/&gt;
									xmlConfig.setProperty(key, value);&lt;br/&gt;
									xmlConfig.save();&lt;/p&gt;

</description>

                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="13204322" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 9 Feb 2012 07:23:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Can you log the URL of the configuration you want to save: xmlConfig.getURL() ?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Without knowing too many details about JBoss&apos;s deployment mechanism, I assume that your application is not directly executed from the deploy folder, but copied into a working directory. Therefore, you probably end up with a URL pointing to a file in a virtual JBoss file system. That this file cannot be written is pretty clear.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In general, I do not think that it is a good idea to manipulate content of an application folder which has been deployed to a server. The directory is under control of the application server, and changing it - if possible at all - may have undesired side effects.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Further, I doubt that this issue is specific to Commons Configuration. You can check whether you are able to read, manipulate, and save any other file from your application directory.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13229616" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 14 Mar 2012 21:08:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Any news here? I tend to close this ticket as I do not think we can do anything about it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13426051" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Tue, 31 Jul 2012 19:36:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Got no more feedback, so closing as invalid.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-477] PropertyListConfiguration cannot deal with comments</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-477</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;According to &lt;a href=&quot;http://code.google.com/p/networkpx/wiki/PlistSpec&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://code.google.com/p/networkpx/wiki/PlistSpec&lt;/a&gt; a plist file can contain C-style comments. These are currently not recognized by &lt;tt&gt;PropertyListConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12540610">CONFIGURATION-477</key>
            <summary>PropertyListConfiguration cannot deal with comments</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="oheger">Oliver Heger</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="oheger">Oliver Heger</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 31 Jan 2012 20:56:42 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 18:07:22 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 16 Mar 2012 19:56:42 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.9</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Format</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13212534" author="ebourg" created="Tue, 21 Feb 2012 12:18:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The specification I used to implement it didn&apos;t mention that comments were allowed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.gnustep.org/resources/documentation/Developer/Base/Reference/NSPropertyList.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.gnustep.org/resources/documentation/Developer/Base/Reference/NSPropertyList.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I checked the plist parser in the OpenStep code and it does indeed skip C-style comments (both block comments and line comments):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;/*
 *	Property list parsing - skip whitespace keeping count of lines and
 *	regarding objective-c style comments as whitespace.
 *	Returns YES &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; there is any non-whitespace text remaining.
 */
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; BOOL skipSpace(pldata *pld)
{
  unsigned &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;char&lt;/span&gt;	c;

  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;while&lt;/span&gt; (pld-&amp;gt;pos &amp;lt; pld-&amp;gt;end)
    {
      c = pld-&amp;gt;ptr[pld-&amp;gt;pos];

      &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (GS_IS_WHITESPACE(c) == NO)
	{
	  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (c == &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;/&apos;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;&amp;amp; pld-&amp;gt;pos &amp;lt; pld-&amp;gt;end - 1)
	    {
	      /*
	       * Check &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; comments beginning &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;/&apos;&lt;/span&gt; followed by &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;/&apos;&lt;/span&gt; or &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;*&apos;&lt;/span&gt;
	       */
	      &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (pld-&amp;gt;ptr[pld-&amp;gt;pos + 1] == &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;/&apos;&lt;/span&gt;)
		{
		  pld-&amp;gt;pos += 2;
		  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;while&lt;/span&gt; (pld-&amp;gt;pos &amp;lt; pld-&amp;gt;end)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13231563" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 16 Mar 2012 19:56:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in subversion in revision 1301722.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-476] Possible ClassCastException in CompositeConfiguration if a special in-memory configuration is used</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-476</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Some methods of &lt;tt&gt;CompositeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; expect that the in-memory configuration is of type &lt;tt&gt;BaseConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; (a configuration of this type is created if no specific in-memory configuration was provided).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, there are constructors accepting an arbitrary &lt;tt&gt;Configuration&lt;/tt&gt; object as in-memory configuration. If here a configuration is specified which does not extend &lt;tt&gt;BaseConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;, the casts performed by these methods will fail. The casts should only be performed if possible.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following methods are affected:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;setListDelimiter()&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;setDelimiterParsingDisabled()&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12538459">CONFIGURATION-476</key>
            <summary>Possible ClassCastException in CompositeConfiguration if a special in-memory configuration is used</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-474] Lists don&apos;t seem to work whean loading INI files</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-474</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;After loading an INI file with HierarchicalINIConfiguration, getList() and getStringArray() alaways return 1-size sets even if the parameter is in the right form in the file. To reproduce one only need to create a small INI file with the following content :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;key=val1,val2,val3&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following code returns a 1-sized list :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;HierarchicalINIConfiguration c = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; HierarchicalINIConfiguration();
c.load(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test.ini&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
List&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; l = c.getList(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;val&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;=&amp;gt; l = &lt;tt&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;val1,val2,val3&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/tt&gt; instead of &lt;tt&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;val1&amp;quot;,&amp;quot;val2&amp;quot;,&amp;quot;val3&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I tried to change the list delimiter, but it didn&apos;t work. Maybe it&apos;s expected, but I haven&apos;t found anything in the doc.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12537561">CONFIGURATION-474</key>
            <summary>Lists don&apos;t seem to work whean loading INI files</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="oheger">Oliver Heger</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="clec0917">Charles Leclerc</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 6 Jan 2012 18:27:58 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 4 Feb 2012 16:18:44 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 21 Jan 2012 17:05:10 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.8</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13182020" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 7 Jan 2012 16:27:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Indeed, in contrast to the deprecated INIConfiguration, HierarchicalINIConfiguration does not split comma-separated values. This should be added to be consistend with other configuration implementations. However, I would suggest to disable this feature by default to stay compatible with older versions. So in order to enable it, you would have to call &lt;tt&gt;setDelimiterParsingDisabled(false)&lt;/tt&gt; before calling &lt;tt&gt;load()&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the report.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13182033" author="clec0917" created="Sat, 7 Jan 2012 17:16:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I tried to add &lt;tt&gt;setDelimiterParsingDisabled(false)&lt;/tt&gt; before calling &lt;tt&gt;load()&lt;/tt&gt;, but it doesn&apos;t work either, the List is is still 1-sized.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13190464" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 21 Jan 2012 17:05:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Support for list delimiter parsing has been added in revision 1234362.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, it was not possible to switch off this behavior per default because HierarchicalINIConfiguration has constructors which directly call the load() method. At that moment the &lt;em&gt;delimiterParsingDisabled&lt;/em&gt; flag is always &lt;b&gt;false&lt;/b&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So delimiter parsing now works and is enabled per default (which is alright because it is consistent with other Configuration implementations). I added a corresponding hint to the release notes as this may impact existing code.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-471] CompositeConfiguration delivers value from wrong child</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-471</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I create a composite configuration with two PropertyConfigurations: a user configuration and a default configuration, with the userConfiguration as inMemoryConfiguration.&lt;br/&gt;
If both configurations contain the same key, the value from defaultConfiguration is returned although the user configuration was added first. If no inMemoryConfiguration is specified, it&apos;s working ok:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Configuration defaultConf = new PropertiesConfiguration();&lt;br/&gt;
defaultConf.addProperty(&quot;prop1&quot;, &quot;fromDefaultConfig&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Configuration userConf = new PropertiesConfiguration();&lt;br/&gt;
userConf.addProperty(&quot;prop1&quot;, &quot;fromUserConfig&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;CompositeConfiguration noMemoryConfig = new CompositeConfiguration();&lt;br/&gt;
noMemoryConfig.addConfiguration(userConf);&lt;br/&gt;
noMemoryConfig.addConfiguration(defaultConf);&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(&quot;noMemoryConfig: &quot; + noMemoryConfig.getString(&quot;prop1&quot;)); // Shows &quot;fromUserConfig&quot; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;CompositeConfiguration withMemoryConfig = new CompositeConfiguration(userConf);&lt;br/&gt;
withMemoryConfig.addConfiguration(userConf);&lt;br/&gt;
withMemoryConfig.addConfiguration(defaultConf);&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(&quot;withMemoryConfig: &quot; + withMemoryConfig.getString(&quot;prop1&quot;)); // Shows &quot;fromDefaultConfig&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12530974">CONFIGURATION-471</key>
            <summary>CompositeConfiguration delivers value from wrong child</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="oheger">Oliver Heger</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jwesely">Joerg Wesely</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 09:14:07 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 4 Feb 2012 16:18:45 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 18 Jan 2012 20:55:11 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.8</fixVersion>
                                    <component>File reloading</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13148715" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 11 Nov 2011 20:34:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This behavior is indeed inconsistent.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;From looking at the code, the result is caused by the fact that the inMemoryConfiguration is always stored at the end of the list of managed configurations. Adding of the user configuration in your second example actually does not have any effect because this configuration is already contained (as inMemoryConfiguration). So the order of the configurations is reverse to the desired one. This implementation detail and its consequences are not documented.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I assume, the original authors of CompositeConfiguration did not intend that a single configuration could be used as both child configuration and inMemoryConfiguration. I am not sure how to proceed. In any case, documentation should be improved. However, changing the behavior of CompositeConfiguration in this respect might break existing code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thinking about a workaround, would it be possible to use the default inMemoryConfiguration and register an event listener at it which just copies all changes to the user configuration? Of course, this means more effort.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13188694" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 18 Jan 2012 20:55:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;An overloaded version of &lt;tt&gt;addConfiguration()&lt;/tt&gt; was added which expects an additional boolean parameter. If set to &lt;b&gt;true&lt;/b&gt;, the newly added configuration becomes the in-memory configuration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When used this way, no re-ordering of child configurations is done. This solves the problem described in this ticket: Just create a &lt;tt&gt;CompositeConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; using the default constructor, and then add the child configurations in the desired order. For the child configuration which should become the in-memory configuration set the flag to &lt;b&gt;true&lt;/b&gt;. Then everything should work as desired.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The new functionality is available in subversion in revision 1233058.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>

                        <customfieldname>Rank (Obsolete)</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>177216</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310222" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:timeinstatus">
                        <customfieldname>Time in Status</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>

    </item>


<item>

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-469</link>

                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I am getting the following error when I use commons configuration under JBoss. Standalone application is working fine.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-465] OSGI issue - configuration depends on Jexl 1.0 which does not have OSGI release</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-465</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I updated to use commons-configuration 1.7 (from 1.6) and am running into the following resolution error under Eclipse Equinox OSGi framework.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        An Import-Package could not be resolved. Caused by missing constraint in bundle &amp;lt;org.apache.commons.configuration_1.7.0&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
             constraint: &amp;lt;Import-Package: org.apache.commons.jexl; version=&quot;0.0.0&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;According to the Import-Package header in 1.7&apos;s MANIFEST.MF, commons-configuration now has a required dependency on org.apache.commons.jexl.  Problem is, there is no OSGi enabled version of Apache Commons jexl that exports this package.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In jexl 2.0 the packages were renamed and org.apache.commons.jexl2 is exported.  The 1.x codeline, although using org.apache.commons.jexl, does not have the appropriate MANIFEST.MF headers to be used as an OSGi bundle.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As such, you cannot consume commons-configuration 1.7 in an OSGi environment.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12525552">CONFIGURATION-465</key>
            <summary>OSGI issue - configuration depends on Jexl 1.0 which does not have OSGI release</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="richmayfield">Rich Mayfield</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 3 Oct 2011 17:28:04 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 4 Feb 2012 16:18:45 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 22 Jan 2012 16:25:04 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.8</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13119887" author="ralph.goers@dslextreme.com" created="Tue, 4 Oct 2011 03:58:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Jexl is used in the ExprLookup class. If you don&apos;t use it in your DefaultConfigurationBuilder configuration then Jexl would not be required. I didn&apos;t realize that Jexl had this issue so I appreciate you letting us know about it. Jexl 2.x requires Java 1.5 so it would definitely have to be an optional dependency since Commons Configuration supports Java 1.4.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13119975" author="richmayfield" created="Tue, 4 Oct 2011 09:19:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the response.  By default, packages listed in the MANIFEST.MF Import-Package header is considered required.  You can, however, make package imports &quot;optional&quot; in cases like you have described.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If it is the case that the class that references Jexl (ExprLookup) is never loaded via the bundle classloader for commons-configuration, then making that package dependency optional should do the trick.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13120035" author="richmayfield" created="Tue, 4 Oct 2011 12:39:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I guess I should add, and I hinted at this in the defect submission: Even if you do make that package optional the use of ExprLookup will be dependent upon a new release of Jexl 1.x that includes the OSGi MANIFEST.MF headers to export packages.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the Jexl project does not plan to update it&apos;s 1.x distribution perhaps someone might &quot;bundle-ize&quot; the 1.x distribution and make it available via the SpringSource Bundle Repository.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;At the very least though making it optional will allow anyone not using Jexl to leverage the new version of commons-configuration in an OSGi environment.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13190475" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sat, 21 Jan 2012 17:35:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As configuration 1.8 will target Java 1.5, it is possible to switch to a Jexl 2.x version. AIUI this should solve this problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I committed a change which sets the Jexl version to the most recent 2.1.1. A few adjustments in &lt;tt&gt;ExprLookup&lt;/tt&gt; were necessary. Ralph, can you have a short review whether may changes are correct (I am not familar with Jexl)? The unit test is still green.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13190624" author="ralph.goers@dslextreme.com" created="Sun, 22 Jan 2012 08:04:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As far as I can tell the changes look OK, assuming JexlEngine is thread-safe. If the unit tests are passing then these chagnes should be OK.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13190697" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 22 Jan 2012 15:45:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for reviewing.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I was also wondering whether the Jexl classes are thread-safe and finally found the information (in the package documentation for o.a.c.jexl2) that JexlEngine actually is. However, I doubt that the same is true for MapContext because it is just a wrapper around a HashMap. Therefore, I am going to change the implementation to create a new context every time rather than caching it in a member field.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13190705" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 22 Jan 2012 16:25:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Switched to version 2.1.1 of Commons Jexl. This dependency should be resolvable in an OSGi environment.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

            <title>[CONFIGURATION-464] Download URL incorrect.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-464</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This is a website issue, so apologies if I&apos;m reporting in the wrong place.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The link provided on the downloads page is &lt;/p&gt;
{mirror}/commons/configuration/binaries/commons-configuration-1.7.zip whereas the actual filename has a &apos;-bin&apos; suffix: {mirror}
&lt;p&gt;/commons/configuration/binaries/commons-configuration-1.7-bin.zip .  Can be worked around by amending the URL in the browser.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;N/A&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12525170">CONFIGURATION-464</key>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-463] AbstractFileConfiguration.load(String filename) returns with current directory changed</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-463</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    PropertiesConfiguration pc = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; PropertiesConfiguration();
    ...
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; f : cl.getArgs())
    {
        pc.load(f);
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Invoked in directory /home/me/test with several relative paths, i.e. ./sub1/a.cfg ./sub2/b.cfg&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;First file loads successfully. Upon return from the first invocation of pc.load(f), the current directory has been changed to the absolute path of the loaded file (/home/me/test/sub1).  Thus, subsequent paths given as relative references to the original user.dir fail to be found.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If this is the expected behavior, it should be documented.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows7, Linux (Fedora14)&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12524961">CONFIGURATION-463</key>
            <summary>AbstractFileConfiguration.load(String filename) returns with current directory changed</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jgarrison@troux.com">James Garrison</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 27 Sep 2011 19:47:52 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 4 Feb 2012 16:18:46 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 20 Jan 2012 20:37:48 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.6</version>
                    <version>1.7</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.8</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13116769" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 28 Sep 2011 20:26:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Your observation is correct, &lt;tt&gt;AbstractFileConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; indeed changes its internal base path the first time a file is loaded. It behaves this way for a long time, so it is probably a bad idea to change this now (at least in the 1.x series).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But you are right, the documentation should mention this behavior.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13190076" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Fri, 20 Jan 2012 20:37:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The Javadoc of the class and the load() methods was updated accordingly. Fixed in revision 1234118.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-460] reloadStrategy does not work for files inside &lt;additional&gt; tag using DefaultConfigurationBuilder</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-460</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In the configuration file that DefaultConfigurationBuilder reads to build a CombinedConfiguration, it&apos;s possible to include configuration file either inside &amp;lt;override&amp;gt; or &amp;lt;additional&amp;gt; xml elements.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Each such declaration, of a file, allows a realodStrategy to be specified (see example below). It appears that the reload occurs only for the files inside &amp;lt;override&amp;gt; and not for the ones inside &amp;lt;additional&amp;gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;configuration&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &amp;lt;header&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;result forceReloadCheck=&quot;true&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      &amp;lt;expressionEngine config-class=&quot;org.apache.commons.configuration.tree.xpath.XPathExpressionEngine&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;/result&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &amp;lt;/header&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &amp;lt;override&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;properties fileName=&quot;user.properties&quot; config-optional=&quot;true&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      &amp;lt;reloadingStrategy refreshDelay=&quot;100&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
                         config-class=&quot;org.apache.commons.configuration.reloading.FileChangedReloadingStrategy&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;/properties&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &amp;lt;/override&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &amp;lt;additional&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;properties fileName=&quot;application.properties&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      &amp;lt;reloadingStrategy refreshDelay=&quot;100&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
                         config-class=&quot;org.apache.commons.configuration.reloading.FileChangedReloadingStrategy&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;/properties&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &amp;lt;/additional&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/configuration&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In above example, both user.properties and application.properties are supposed to reload upon change. However, as tested by the following code, one user.properties gets reloaded:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		DefaultConfigurationBuilder dcb = new DefaultConfigurationBuilder(&quot;example.xml&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
		Configuration conf = dcb.getConfiguration();&lt;br/&gt;
		System.out.println(&quot;user: &quot; + conf.getBoolean(&quot;user&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
		System.out.println(&quot;application: &quot; + conf.getBoolean(&quot;application&quot;));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		System.out.println(&quot;Change files and then press  to continue...&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
		System.in.read();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		System.out.println(&quot;user: &quot; + conf.getBoolean(&quot;user&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
		System.out.println(&quot;application: &quot; + conf.getBoolean(&quot;application&quot;));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Output from above code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;user: true&lt;br/&gt;
application: true&lt;br/&gt;
Change files and then press  to continue...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;0 &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;main&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; INFO org.apache.commons.configuration.PropertiesConfiguration  - Reloading configuration. URL is file:&amp;lt;snipped&amp;gt;/user.properties&lt;br/&gt;
user: false&lt;br/&gt;
application: true&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Linux x86_64&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12518616">CONFIGURATION-460</key>
            <summary>reloadStrategy does not work for files inside &lt;additional&gt; tag using DefaultConfigurationBuilder</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="oheger">Oliver Heger</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="azfarkazmi">Azfar Kazmi</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 11 Aug 2011 17:59:50 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 8 Sep 2011 09:20:13 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 20:22:32 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.6</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.7</fixVersion>
                                    <component>File reloading</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13084900" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 14 Aug 2011 20:32:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The problem is probably caused by the structure of the combined configuration produced by &lt;tt&gt;DefaultConfigurationBuilder&lt;/tt&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;There is one &lt;tt&gt;CombinedConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; which stores all properties. It is configured by properties in the &lt;em&gt;result&lt;/em&gt; section.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;For configuration sources declared in the &lt;em&gt;additional&lt;/em&gt; section another &lt;tt&gt;CombinedConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt; is created and added to the first &lt;tt&gt;CombinedConfiguration&lt;/tt&gt;. This configuration, however, is currently not fully initialized. Especially the &lt;em&gt;forceReloadCheck&lt;/em&gt; property is not set. Therefore reloads are not detected.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;A fix for this issue has to ensure that some of the properties defined for the result configuration are also set for the configuration for the additional sources.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13085305" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 15 Aug 2011 20:22:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A fix was applied in SVN revision 1157982. Thank you for reporting this.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-458] SubnodeConfiguration.clear() does not work correctly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-458</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If clear() is called on a SubnodeConfiguration obtained through the configurationAt() method of HierarchicalConfiguration, the node structure of the parent configuration (outside of the area of the sub configuration) may also be manipulated. Properties added to the SubnodeConfiguration after a clear() are not visible from the parent configuration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem is caused by the implementation of the clear() method inherited from AbstractConfiguration. This will call clearProperty() for each property found in the configuration. clearProperty() in turn clears the value of nodes and recursively clears the parent node if it does not contain any data. Here the structure owned by the SubnodeConfiguration can be left so that the parent gets manipulated.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A possible solution would be to provide a specific implementation of clear() for hierarchical configurations. This could also be more efficient than the base implementation.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12515952">CONFIGURATION-458</key>
            <summary>SubnodeConfiguration.clear() does not work correctly</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="oheger">Oliver Heger</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 1 Aug 2011 20:02:44 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 2 May 2013 02:29:42 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 2 Aug 2011 20:17:14 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.6</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.7</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-456] AbstractConfiguration.getKeys(String prefix) docs doesn&apos;t say about the point (&apos;.&apos;)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-456</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;For the method org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.getKeys(String prefix) the documentation doesn&apos;t say that to the prefix will be added a point character (&apos;.&apos;) to filter the keys list (&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/configuration/apidocs/org/apache/commons/configuration/AbstractConfiguration.html#getKeys%28java.lang.String%29&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/configuration/apidocs/org/apache/commons/configuration/AbstractConfiguration.html#getKeys%28java.lang.String%29&lt;/a&gt;). I discovered it only reading the source.&lt;br/&gt;
Maybe I should have known this behaviour, but I think a lot of occasional users could face this unpredictable behaviour. Specifying this would be very helpfull.&lt;br/&gt;
Many thanks for your wonderful libraries!&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12515746">CONFIGURATION-456</key>
            <summary>AbstractConfiguration.getKeys(String prefix) docs doesn&apos;t say about the point (&apos;.&apos;)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bluish">Mirco Andreon</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-455] HierachicalINIConfiguration section access without dotted notation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-455</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Setting section properties of previously non-existent Sections using getSection().setProperty() fails.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Using a non existing filename for f, the following produces an empty file.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ini = HierarchicalINIConfiguration(f)&lt;br/&gt;
section = ini.getSection(&quot;section&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
section.setProperty(&quot;foo&quot;, &quot;bar&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
ini.save()&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Accessing SubnodeConfigurations after clearing them fails.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;using an existing file with an existing section, produces an empty file.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ini = new HierarchicalINIConfiguration(f);&lt;br/&gt;
subnode = ini.getSection(&quot;section&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
if (! subnode.isEmpty() ) {&lt;br/&gt;
   subnode.clear();&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
subnode.setProperty(&quot;foo&quot;, &quot;bar&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
ini.save();&lt;/p&gt;



</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12514804">CONFIGURATION-455</key>
            <summary>HierachicalINIConfiguration section access without dotted notation</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

                            <comment id="13068449" author="fragfutter" created="Wed, 20 Jul 2011 15:55:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Bug Example&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13069171" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 21 Jul 2011 20:06:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thank you for reporting this. Hopefully I find some free cycles in a couple of days to have a look at this issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13073689" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Mon, 1 Aug 2011 20:06:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Actually there are two different issues. For the problem with the clear() method I have created a separate issue. It is not related to HierarchicalINIConfiguration, but more general for all hierarchical configurations.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13078990" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Wed, 3 Aug 2011 20:27:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A fix was applied in revision 1153643.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The getSection() method now always returns a SubnodeConfiguration which is connected to the parent configuration. Therefore changes in the section configuration are directly visible in the parent and vice versa. If the section whose name is passed to getSection() does not exist, it is newly created.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Documentation has been updated correspondingly. Also, a warning has been added that the storage scheme of the configuration should not be manipulated by calling addProperty() in an uncontrolled way.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[CONFIGURATION-454] Malformed pom uploaded to repositories</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CONFIGURATION-454</link>
                <project id="12310467" key="CONFIGURATION">Commons Configuration</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The pom downloaded, for example, from:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://uk.maven.org/maven2/commons-configuration/commons-configuration/1.6/commons-configuration-1.6.pom&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://uk.maven.org/maven2/commons-configuration/commons-configuration/1.6/commons-configuration-1.6.pom&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
is damaged: e.g. the &amp;lt;url&amp;gt; is given as:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;url&amp;gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/$&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/$&lt;/a&gt;{pom.artifactId.substring(8)}/&amp;lt;/url&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;directory&amp;gt;${basedir}&amp;lt;/directory&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
etc.&lt;br/&gt;
This affects the generated licenses for other projects.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Compare with commons-collections, which is fine.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Problems seems to be in trunk/project.xml ?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12514337">CONFIGURATION-454</key>
            <summary>Malformed pom uploaded to repositories</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>

                            <comment id="13066530" author="joehni" created="Sat, 16 Jul 2011 20:21:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think this is a left-over from a M1 POM where the POM was actually a Jelly script. Can&apos;t remember currently, but it might be that 1.6 was stilkl released with M1 and the POM you&apos;re facing has been auto-converted&quot; by Maven folks&apos; repository tools.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13100467" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 8 Sep 2011 17:17:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As far as I know, it is impossible to change artifacts in the central maven repository after they have been uploaded. So I doubt that the problem can be fixed for the 1.6 pom.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, version 1.7 has just been released. The pom in maven central looks good. Can you update your dependency to this version? (It should be a drop-in replacement for 1.6.)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13100486" author="kevin-m" created="Thu, 8 Sep 2011 17:37:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sure - I&apos;ll try 1.7. Thanks for the heads-up.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13100497" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 8 Sep 2011 17:52:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Maven Central won&apos;t allow updates to jars etc. because that would mean builds were not repeatable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;They do allow hashes and sigs to be replaced, and they may allow the url to be fixed as it does not affect builds.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Worth reporting in case.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
